TF PPI; Transactivation	Other	Strong	CAT reporter construct with N-CAM promoter containing HBS-I/II binding sites was cotransfected with Hox-2.5, which led to significant expression. Cotransfection with various reporters with mutated binding sites shows that 1) with HBS-I-/II-, there is no CAT activity with or without Hox-2.5; 2) with HBS-I-/II+, activity with Hox-2.5 but not Hox-2.4; 3) with HBs-I+/II-, no CAT activity with either Hox-2.5 or 2.4. When both Hox-2.5 and 2.4 are cotransfected, CAT activity decreases with increasing amount of Hox-2.4, while if Hox-2.4 is fixed and Hox-2.5 is increased, CAT activity increases.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																   		      	    	      		       			 		  9079637	      DNA Binding	      Mouse  Strong   EMSA shows that tagged HOXB9 and PBX1A forms a strong cooperative complex on oligo ATGATGA, whereas HOXB9 alone results in a very weak binding only. Supershifting with anti-tag Ab shows that the complex contains both PBX1A and HOXB9. Mutant HOXB9 with tryptophan replaced is not able to form a complex with PBX1A, but does not prevent DNA binding, as it still shifts DNA. Site selection protocol shows that HOXB9 selectively binds to oligos with TTAC core site, and gel shift assay indicates that HOXB9 and PBX1A cooperatively binds to these oligos, but not other HOX proteins.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																											  		      	  		      	     	      	   	 10617598    Co-activation; DNA Binding; Transactivation	Human	 Strong	  EMSA with GST-HOXB9 and HBSII oligo results in a retarded complex that is competed by unlabeled HBSII, but not by mutated HBSII, and supershifted by GST Ab. Adding his-Btg2 is added to the mix, an additional retarded band is seen, and this band is also competed by unlabled HBSII, and his-Btg2 alone does not result in a retarded band, while it results in a stronger band for HOXB9-DNA. CAT reporter with HBSII binding sites is activated by transfection of Hoxb9, and this is linearly enhanced by cotransfection of Btg1 and Btg2, while Btg1/2 alone do not result in activation. Western blot shows that Btg1/2 do not lead to increased production of Hoxb9. Hoxc8 and Hoxd9 do not lead to increased expression when used in the same experiment, indicating HBSII specificity. Truncated HOXB9 was tested for ability to drive CAT reporter expression to find the transcription activation domain. Transfection study with full-length and truncated GAL4-Btg1/2 fusions and GAL4-CAT reporter fails to activate transcription. GAL4-HOXB9 also fails to drive expression, even when cotransfected with Btg1/2.

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																														  15425	    homeo box C6  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family   Shannan HoSui   TF Gene	 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	     The HOXC6 is highly conserved across vertebrates. Xenopus HoxC6 was shown to bind to mouse N-CAM promoter, which contains two TAAT motifs HBS-I and HBS-II. Binding was shown to be specific via EMSA. HoxC6 strongly activated a CAT reporter gene. A variant of HoxC6 differing in the N-terminal end but still containing the conserved homeobox domain was shown to repress a lucerifase reporter in breast cancer cells (MDA-MB231).	  8393570	 DNA Binding; Transactivation Mouse; Other   Strong		Xenopus HoxC6S fusion protein bound to the mouse N-CAM promoter, a 47 bp segment that contains two TAAT motifs (HBS-I and HBS-II), in gel shift experiments. Competition assays using HBS-I and HBS-II sequences, wild-type and containing mutations in the TAAT core, revealed that binding was specific to HBS-I. Additional support was obtained using three tandem copies of the N-CAM HBS-I motif in EMSA. Cotransfection of CMV-HoxC6 (long and short variants) in NIH 3T3 cells together with the mouse N-CAM promoter/CAT gene reporter plasmid induced CAT reporter gene expression driven by the N-CAM promoter (~7-fold individually and 11.5-fold when both variants were cotransfected). Reporters containing wild-type and mutant HBS-I and HBS-II sequences were also tested for transactivation activity by HoxC6 to a SV40 minimal promoter in cotransfection experiments. The long variant of HoxC6 strongly activated transcription via the HBS-I and HBS-II regions but not from the mutated regions.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																														  	    	      	  		   		     	      8870653 Transactivation	 Mouse	      Medium		     A new variant of HOXC6 encoding a homeodomain-containing protein harbouring a unique N-terminal sequence was cloned and confirmed by RT-PCR. To study the functional properties of both HOXC6 proteins in breast cancer cells, co-transfection experiments with pTCBS as reporter plasmid in MDA-MB231 cells, which do not express detectable levels of HOXC6, were designed. The construct contains a multimerized consensus binding sequence (CBS) that can mediate trans-activation of multiple HOX-derived proteins.  As a positive control for the transfections, HOXD9 gene product, which trans-activates pTCBS in NIH3T3 cells as well as in MDA-MB231 cells was used. Both HOXC6 gene products repress the transcription from the CBS in a dose-dependent manner. Moreover, when co-transfected with HOXB7 gene product, which causes a trans-activation by itself, the 173 or 211 pcDNA3 constructs significantly suppressed the induced expression of the luciferase gene in a dose-dependent manner. The results suggest that both HOXC6 products harbour intrinsic repressing abilities and can co-operate with other HOX-derived proteins on the CBS.

Hox D3 was also shown to promote beta5 expression in vivo.		   14610084  DNA Binding; Transactivation   Human      Strong	   The role of Hox D3 in the regulation of integrin alpha5 beta1 expression was examined. HMEC-1 endothelial cells were stably transfected with pCMV-D3, a Hox D3 expression vector, leading to enhanced Hox D3 expression. Integrin alpha5 mRNA and protein levels were significantly up-regulated by expression of Hox D3 (pCMV-D3) in microvascular endothelial cells in vitro. Conversely, expression of HOX D3 antisense inhibits HOX D3, but not HOX B3 or HOX A3, gene expression as well as alpha5 mRNA expression. Hox D3 had no effect on expression of the 1 integrin subunit. These studies indicate that the transcription factor Hox D3 promotes integrin alpha5 message and protein expression. Direct binding of Hox D3 to the integrin alpha5 and beta3 integrin promoters were confirmed by chromatin cross-linking and immunoprecipitation studies in HMEC stably expressing an HA/Hox D3 expression plasmid. Antibodies against the paralogous Hox B3, which does not affect alpha5 beta3 expression, did not recover the beta 2 integrin promoter.As Hox D3 directly binds to the integrin subunit promoters and also induces their up-regulation in endothelial cells, Hox D3 is likely to directly regulate the expression of these integrins by binding to their promoters and initiating transcription. To test this possibility, a luciferase expression construct under control of the integrin beta 3 promoter was transfected into HMEC stably expressing Hox D3. Transcriptional activation of the beta3 promoter was significantly higher in Hox D3-expressing HMEC as compared with control HMEC. Mutation of two putative Hox-binding sites within the beta3 promoter resulted in the loss of Hox D3-dependent transcriptional activity. In contrast, activity of the MMP-14 promoter was similar in both control and Hox D3-expressing HMEC.To determine whether Hox D3 regulates integrin alpha5 beta1 expression in vivo, chick chorioallantoic membranes stimulated with saline, Del-1, or bFGF were transfected with Hox D3 sense or antisense constructs. Application of either bFGF or Del-1 to CAMs stimulates angiogenesis and induces alpha5 beta1 expression. Integrin alphav beta5 expression remains unchanged upon treatment with bFGF or Del-1, however. Hox D3 antisense suppresses 5 expression in vivo. Expression of Hox D3 antisense suppresses chicken Hox D3 but not chicken Hox B3, indicating that the human Hox D3 antisense construct suppresses chicken Hox D3 expression and thereby integrin expression. These results indicate that Hox D3 regulates integrin 5 expression in vitro and in vivo.

Epub 2003 Feb 5.A hybrid IRF9-STAT2 protein recapitulates interferon-stimulated gene expressionand antiviral response.Kraus TA, Lau JF, Parisien JP, Horvath CM.Immunobiology Center, The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, New York, New York10029, USA.Type I interferon (IFN) signaling induces the heterotrimeric transcriptioncomplex, IFN-stimulated gene factor (ISGF) 3, which contains STAT1, STAT2, andthe DNA binding subunit, interferon regulatory factor (IRF) 9. Because IRF9 istargeted to the nucleus in the absence of IFN stimulation, the potential of IRF9protein for gene regulation was examined using a GAL4 DNA binding domain fusionsystem. GAL4-IRF9 was transcriptionally active in reporter gene assays but not inthe absence of cellular STAT1 and STAT2. However, the inert IRF9 protein wasreadily converted to a constitutively active ISGF3-like activator by fusion withthe C-terminal transcriptional activation domain of STAT2 or the acidicactivation domain of herpesvirus VP16. The IRF9 hybrids are targeted toendogenous ISGF3 target loci and can activate their transcription. Moreover,expression of the IRF9-STAT2 fusion can recapitulate the type I IFN biologicalresponse, producing a cellular antiviral state that protects cells fromvirus-induced cytopathic effects and inhibits virus replication. The antiviralstate generated by regulated IRF9-STAT2 hybrid protein expression is independentof autocrine IFN signaling and inhibits both RNA and DNA viruses.

Transcriptional regulation by LHX3 is complex, involving DNA binding-dependent actions mediated by the HD and transcriptional activation mediated by a major activation domain located in the carboxyl terminus and weaker activation functions in other domains. In experiments using pituitary hormone reporter genes, LHX3 has been demonstrated to function both alone and in synergy with other transcription factors, such as PIT1. In addition, in the developing nervous system, LHX3 is proposed to participate in gene regulatory complexes that include other LIM-HD proteins, such as islet 1 (ISL1), and LIM-interacting partners, such as nuclear LIM interactor (NLI)/cofactor of LIM proteins (CLIM).	15271874	DNA Binding	Mouse	Strong	Human and Mouse Lim Homeobox 3 genes were clones and used for ChIP experiment. Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding	      Mbd1 is a transcription factor. It has be shown to bind and transrepress both methylated and non-methylated DNA-reporter genes (by EMSA) and targets heterochromatic foci in spite of their methylated status (by immunocytochemistry studies).	15060159	DNA Binding	Human; Mouse	Strong	EMSA demonstrates Mbd1 CXXC-3 region for unmethylated CpG dinucleotide DNA binding activity.  All Mbd1 isoforms repress a methylated reporter gene in HeLa cells.Mbd1 protein targets heterochromatic foci in spite of their unmethylated status  as demonstrated by immunocytochemistry in wild type and mutant (less than 5% of the normal level of DNA methylation) mouse embryonic fibroblasts. 17285		     mesenchyme homeobox 1	  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family Shannan HoSui   TF Gene  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	 Meox1 has been shown to activate transcription of the Bax1 gene by binding to a TAATTA sequence. The binding site was identified using deletion constructs in transient tranfections assays combined with EMSA assays. Transactivation of Bax1 was enhanced in the presence of Pax1 and Pax9.	15024065	Co-activation; DNA Binding; TF PPI; Transactivation	Mouse	Strong	The plasmid p5.3Bp-luc, which contained a fragment of about 5.5 kb of the mouse Bapx1 promoter followed by the luciferase reporter gene was used in transient transfection assays to determine if Meox genes maintain Bapx1 expression by direct activation of its transcription. This construct has previously been shown to be transactivated by Pax1 and Pax9. p5.3Bp-luc was cotransfected with increasing amounts of the Meox1 expression vector pMeox1 in NIH 3T3 cells. pMeox1 induced a dose-dependent activation of the Bapx1 promoter, up to fourfold. This transactivation effect of Meox1 was specific for Bapx1 regulatory sequences, as Meox1 did not activate the control vector pGL3-Basic or pGL3-Promoter, a reporter vector containing an SV40 promoter upstream of the luciferase gene.The Meox1 and Pax1 proteins can interact in the yeast two-hybrid system as well as in a pulldown assay (22). Sclerotomal transcription factors Pax1 and Pax9 can transactivate the Bapx1 promoter (21). In transient transfection assays, Pax1 alone increased Bapx1 promoter activity around threefold. Cotransfection of the p5.3Bp-luc plasmid with increasing amounts of the Meox1 expression vector together with the Pax1 expression vector further stimulated the promoter activity eightfold over the basal level.  Maximal Bapx1 promoter activity was achieved in the presence of the three factors Pax1, Pax9, and Meox1.Transient transfection assays with a series of deletion constructs of the Bapx1 promoter were performed to identify Bapx1 binding sites. Meox1-responsive element(s) were located between positions -880 and +109 of the Bapx1 gene. EMSA confirmed that in vitro-synthesized Meox1 protein formed a retarded complex with DNA fragment C in this region. Further EMSA experiments were performed using oligonucleotides based on conserved sequences containing predicted binding sites. When these labeled oligonucleotides were incubated with Meox1 protein, a specific retarded complex was observed only with the B5 oligonucleotide. The specificity of this complex was further confirmed by the addition of an anti-Meox1 antibody to the binding reaction, which induced the formation of a supershifted band together with a strong decrease in the intensity of the Meox1-B5 retarded complex. Competitive binding assays identified a TAATTA sequence to which Meox1 binds. Regulation via this sequence was confirmed by luciferase assay.

   17300	    forkhead box C1    Winged Helix-Turn-Helix/Forkhead Domain Family		    Jared Roach		    TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific   OMIM: "Saleem et al. (2001) investigated 5 missense mutations of the FOXC1 transcription factor found in patients with Axenfeld-Rieger malformations to determine their effects on FOXC1 structure and function. ... DNA-binding experiments revealed that although the S82T and S131L  mutations decreased DNA binding, the F112S  and I126M mutations did not. However, the F112S and I126M mutations decreased the transactivation ability of FOXC1. All the FOXC1 mutations had the net effect of reducing FOXC1 transactivation ability. These results indicated that the FOXC1 forkhead domain contains separable DNA-binding and transactivation functions."	11179011	DNA Binding	Other	Medium	Saleem et al. (2001) investigated 5 missense mutations of the FOXC1 transcription factor found in patients with Axenfeld-Rieger malformations to determine their effects on FOXC1 structure and function. Molecular modeling of the FOXC1 forkhead domain predicted that the missense mutations did not alter FOXC1 structure. Biochemical analyses indicated that whereas all mutant proteins correctly localized to the cell nucleus, the I87M (601090.0009) mutation reduced FOXC1 protein levels. DNA-binding experiments revealed that although the S82T (601090.0008) and S131L (601090.0002) mutations decreased DNA binding, the F112S (601090.0004) and I126M (601090.0003) mutations did not. However, the F112S and I126M mutations decreased the transactivation ability of FOXC1. All the FOXC1 mutations had the net effect of reducing FOXC1 transactivation ability. These results indicated that the FOXC1 forkhead domain contains separable DNA-binding and transactivation functions. In addition, these findings demonstrated that reduced stability, DNA binding, or transactivation, all causing a decrease in the ability of FOXC1 to transactivate genes, can underlie Axenfeld-Rieger malformations. Saleem et al. (2003) studied an additional 5 missense mutations in the FOXC1 gene. Biologic analyses indicated that all missense mutations studied caused various FOXC1 perturbations, including nuclear localization defects, reduced or abolished DNA binding capacity, and a reduction in the transactivation capacity of FOXC1. 30 PubMed Neighbors

  17420		    menage a trois 1			     		Stuart Lithwick	   TF Gene    Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; Basal Transcription Factor	    Mnat1 is a basal transcriptional cofactor, which influences the phosphorylation of RNA polymerase as a subunit of the TFIIH multiprotein complex. Mnat1 (Human ortholog MAT1 is used in this PMID) interacts with TFIIH via a C-terminal domain as demonstrated by affinity chromatography. Also, the presence of MAT1 (specifically the RING finger domain) leads to increased transcription from template promoters and increased phosphorylation of RNA Polymerase II as demonstrated by in-vitro transcription assay and Western blotting.	10801852	Co-activation; TF PPI	Human	Strong	In an affinity chromatography assay, nuclear extracts of Sf9 cells infected with baculovirus vectors carrying either human MAT1 (wt and mutants), all subunits of the core TFIIH subcomplex (XPB, XPD, p62, p52, p44, and p34), cdk7 (wt or mutated in its ATP-binding site), or cyclin H were incubated with antibodies against TFIIH subunits in affinity columns, and retained proteins once eluted were then analyzed by Western blot. Wild-type MAT1, as well as RING finger domain mutants MAT1-C9Y, MAT1-C26S and MAT1[66-309] were retained by TFIIH factors, while mutant MAT1[1-189] was not. In an in-vitro transcription assay, in which TFIIH complex components were incubated with RNA polymerase II (RNA Pol II), basal transcription factors, MAT1, either the adenovirus 2 major late promoter or the DHFR promoter as templates, and NTPs, the presence of wild-type (wt) MAT1 led to 8-10 fold increased transcription from both promoters while MAT1 RING finger domain mutants (MAT1[66-309], MAT1-C9Y and MAT1-C26S) did not stimulate transcription. In addition, through SDS PAGE followed by Western blotting using anti-RNA Pol II (large subunit), increased RNA Pol II phosphorylation was observed in the presence of wt MAT1. Less of an increase in phosphorylation was observed in the presence of MAT1 RING finger domain mutants.

      17702	    homeobox, msh-like 2    Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family	   Wyeth Wasserman	TF Gene	 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	Key papers suggest Msx2 acts often as a suppressor of transcription by blocking binding of other TFs.  Artificial fusion protein shown to bind a target sequence in vitro (EMSA).	9368026	Transactivation	Mouse	Strong	Evidence for sequence specific binding and role in regulating expression.Quoting from the abstract: "We identified the Osteocalcin (OC)  gene as a target for transcriptional suppression by Msx2, a homeodomain transcription factor that controls ossification in the developing skull. In this study, we examine the effects of Msx2 expression on OC promoter activation (luciferase reporter) by FGF2/FSK and calcitriol in MC3T3-E1 osteoblasts. Expression of Msx2 decreases basal activity of the 1-kilobase (-1050 to +32) rat OC promoter by 80%; however, the promoter is still inducible 3-fold by calcitriol. By contrast, OC promoter induction by FGF2/FSK is completely abrogated by Msx2. Because intrinsic Msx2 DNA binding activity is not required for the Msx2 suppressor function, we assessed whether Msx2 represses OC activation by regulating DNA-protein interactions at the FGF2 response element (OCFRE) and compared these interactions with those occurring at the calcitriol response element (VDRE). Treatment of MC3T3-E1 cells with FGF2/FSK or calcitriol up-regulates specific DNA-protein interactions at the OCFRE or VDRE, respectively, as detected by gel shift assay. Preincubation of crude nuclear extracts with recombinant glutathione S-transferase (GST)-Msx2 dose-dependently inhibits OCFRE DNA binding activity, whereas GST has no effect. Msx2 itself does not bind the OCFRE. Residues 132-148 required for Msx2 core suppressor function in transfection assays are also required to inhibit OCFRE DNA binding activity. By contrast, GST-Msx2 has no effect on calcitriol-regulated DNA-protein interactions at the VDRE. Using gel shift as an assay, the OCFRE DNA-binding protein OCFREB was purified to about 50% homogeneity from MG63 osteosarcoma cells. Recombinant Msx2 inhibits purified OCFREB DNA binding activity, whereas the Msx2 variant lacking residues 132-148 is inactive. Thus, Msx2 abrogates up-regulation of the OC promoter by FGF2/FSK in part by inhibiting OCFREB binding to the OCFRE."
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																       		    	      	       	    		     		       		   11798166		DNA Binding	      Other		Medium	   Chicken Msx2-GST fusion protein binds target sequence.Quote from abstract:"The apical ectodermal ridge (AER) is a specialized ectodermal region essential for limb outgrowth. Msx2 expression patterns in limb development strongly suggest an important role for Msx2 in the AER. Our previous studies identified a 348-bp fragment of the chicken Msx2 gene with AER enhancer activity. In this study, the functions of four potential homeodomain binding TAAT sites in this enhancer were studied using transgenic mice and in vitro protein-DNA interactions. Transgenic studies indicate that the four TAAT sites are not redundant and that only the B-TAAT site is critical for AER enhancer activity. The expression patterns of Msx2 and Dlx5 genes in the AER suggest that they might be involved in the regulation of Msx2. In support of this hypothesis, we found that Msx2 and Dlx5 can bind to the B-TAAT site as well as to a fragment containing the D- and E-TAAT sites in the Msx2 AER enhancer sequences."
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																											   			    		      Shannan HoSui	TF Gene	   Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	       MSX2 suppresses transcription via the OC promoter as shown by luciferase assay.  Far western analysis revealed interactions of MSX2 with TFIIF, a component of the basal transcriptional machinery.  DNA binding via the homeobox domain and helix 3 was shown by gel shift; however, direct binding is not required for suppression. Furthermore, Dlx5 reverses Msx2 repression via protein-protein interactions.  9265625  Co-activation; TF PPI	  Mouse	   Medium   Systematic structure-function analyses of Msx2 was performed using OC promoter suppression (luciferase reporter) in MC3T3-E1 calvarial osteoblasts as an assay. Functional analyses of N- and C-terminally truncated molecules identify Msx2 residues 97-208 as the core suppressor domain. A Msx2 point mutant Msx2(T147A) that completely lacks DNA binding activity is indistinguishable from wild-type Msx2 in its ability to suppress the OC promoter, demonstrating that direct interaction with DNA is not required for Msx2 suppressor function. This suggests that Msx2 suppresses transcription via protein-protein interactions with components of the basal transcriptional machinery, either alone or in concert with co-regulators. Msx2 binds both components of TFIIF (RAP74, RAP30), but not TFIIB or TBP, identified via interaction "Far Western" blotting assays.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																      	      		   	   		 		 12750290     TF PPI	       Mouse; Rat      Strong	     In both primary rat calvarial and MC3T3E1 mouse calvarial osteoblasts, transient expression of Dlx5 only mildly augments basal OC promoter (luciferase reporter) activity, while Msx2 suppresses transcriptional activity by ca. 80%. However, Dlx5 completely reverses Msx2 repression of the OC promoter. Structure- function analyses using far-Western blot and transient cotransfection assays reveal that (i) Msx2 and Dlx5 can form dimers, (ii) Dlx5 residues 127-143 are necessary for dimerization and to reverse Msx2-dependent OC repression, and (iii) intrinsic DNA binding activity of Dlx5 is not required for OC regulation. Msx2 inhibits the DNA binding activity of a third complex, OCFREB, that supports activity of the basal OC promoter. Dlx5 completely abrogates Msx2 suppression of OCFREB DNA binding activity, and residues required for Dlx5 transcriptional de-repression in vivo are also required for reversing inhibition of OCFREB binding in vitro.

     	       	       							    	   16767079	   DNA Binding			 Human	Strong	Data shows that recognition of Myc-binding sites is based on epigenetic features. Euchromatic islands, defined as clusters of specific methyl- and acetyl-histone marks at the 5' end of active or poised genes, are required for Myc to bind DNA. E-boxes outside of euchromatic islands are not significantly bound, whereas virtually all E-boxes within euchromatic islands are bound as demonstrated by quantitative chromatin immunoprecipitation, methylation-sensitive restriction enzyme digestion, and bisulphite genomic sequencing.

    17928	 myogenin Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family			 Gwenael Breard	     TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific Myogenin belongs to the myogenic regulatory factors (MRFs), a part of a superfamily of basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH) transcription factors. The MRF proteins contain a conserved basic DNA-binding domain essential for sequence-specific DNA binding and a helix-loop-helix motif required for heterodimerization. Each of the MRFs has been shown to heterodimerize in vitro and in vivo with E proteins and to bind DNA in a sequence-specific manner at sites known as E-boxes (CANNTG). This DNA motif is present in the promoters of many skeletal muscle-specific genes and mediates gene activation in an MRF-dependent manner. Several studies have identified specific enhancer elements for MyoD and myogenin. Induction of the myogenin gene has been shown to be dependent on an E-box and a myocyte enhancer factor-2 element for proper expression in the somites and limbs of the developing mouse, suggesting that its expression is MRF-dependent, in part.	10733231	DNA Binding	Human	Strong	Review assessing what is known on The molecular regulation of myogenesis in 2000

    17933	 myelin transcription factor 1-like	     Zinc-coordinating Group/BetaBetaAlpha-zinc finger Family	  Shannan HoSui	  TF Gene	 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	  The myelin transcription factor 1 (Myt1) family represents neural zinc finger proteins of a structurally novel CCHHC class that were originally cloned by their binding to the promoter of the most abundantly expressed myelin gene, proteolipid protein. The consensus DNA-binding domain of the Myt1 family is Cys-X4-Cys-X4-His-X7-His-X5-Cys (also termed CCHHC domains).  Myt1-Like (Myt1L/neural zinc finger(NZF)-1/Png-1) has been shown to bind to DNA is a sequence-specific manner by competitive EMSA. Transactivation has also been shown by luciferase reporter assays.	8631881	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Rat	Strong	The primary amino acid sequence of the NZF-1 protein (Myt1l) suggested that the protein would contain two clusters of zinc fingers capable of serving as independent DNA binding domains. Competitive EMSA using bacterially expressed glutathione S-transferase fusion protins demonstrated that specific binding of NZF-1 to the beta-RARE DNA element requires a minimum of two zinc fingers. Mutations altering this element revealed that the GAAAGTT motif is critical for binding by two zinc fingers.NZF-1 also contains regions such as acidic and serine/threonine-rich sequences commonly found in the the activation domains of many transcription factors. The potential transcriptional effects of NZF-1 were examined in CV-1 and HeLa cells, which do not contain detectable NZF-1 mRNA by RNase protection assay. NZF-1 has been shown to bind beta-RARE and Pit-1 enhancer elements in a sequence specific manner. Cotransfection of NSF-1 (under the control of the RSV promoter) and hRAR-beta promoter-luciferase reporter plasmid showed that NZF-1 moderately activated the hRAR-beta promoter ~3-fold. Cotransfection with a Pit-1 enhancer luciferase reporter in HeLa cells showed that NZF-1 activated the reporter 4-fold.

this gene most likely a co-factor.	14662770	Co-activation	Unknown	Medium	co-immunoprecipitation of AR and TIF2 may mean NCOA2 functions as a co-factorAbstract: Growth of normal and neoplastic prostate is mediated by the androgen receptor (AR), a ligand-dependent transcription factor activated by high affinity androgen binding. [...] In this report, we show that epidermal growth factor (EGF) increases androgen-dependent AR transactivation in the recurrent prostate cancer cell line CWR-R1 through a mechanism that involves a post-transcriptional increase in the p160 coactivator transcriptional intermediary factor 2/glucocorticoid receptor interacting protein 1 (TIF2/GRIP1)  [aka NCOa2]. Site-specific mutagenesis and selective MAPK inhibitors linked the EGF-induced increase in AR transactivation to phosphorylation of TIF2/GRIP1. EGF signaling increased the coimmunoprecipitation of TIF2 and AR. AR transactivation and its stimulation by EGF were reduced by small interfering RNA inhibition of TIF2/GRIP1 expression. The data indicate that EGF signaling through MAPK increases TIF2/GRIP1 coactivation of AR transactivation in recurrent prostate cancer.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																														  	  	   	       	      	    		 15983373 Other		Mouse  Medium	nuclear localization supports role as co-factor as opposed to binding AR in another capacity.Abstract: Genetic disruption of the steroid receptor coactivator (SRC)-1 and transcriptional intermediary factor (TIF)2/SRC-2 in mouse resulted in distinctive mutant phenotypes. To quantify their roles in the function of androgen receptor (AR) transcriptional activity in vivo, we generated a unique transgenic AR-reporter mouse and analyzed the cell-specific contributions of SRC-1 and TIF2 to the activity of AR in mouse testis. Transgenic AR-luciferase and transgenic AR-lacZ mice harbor a recombinant mouse AR gene, AR(GAL4DBD), which is functionally coupled with a upstream activation sequence-mediated reporter gene (AR activity indicator). After characterization of these mice in terms of AR function, we further derived bigenic mice by crossing AR activity indicator mice with the SRC-1-/- or TIF2+/- mutant mice. Analyses of the resultant bigenic mice by in vivo imaging and luciferase assays showed that testicular AR activity was decreased significantly in those with the TIF2+/- mutation but not in the SRC-1+/- background, suggesting that TIF2 serves as the preferential coactivator for AR in testis. Immunohistological analysis confirmed that AR and TIF2 coexist in mouse testicular Sertoli cell nuclei under normal conditions. Although SRC-1 concentrates in Sertoli cell nuclei in the absence of TIF2, nuclear SRC-1 is not able to rescue AR activity in the TIF2 mutant background. Interestingly, SRC-1 appears to negatively influence AR activity, thereby counterbalancing the TIF2-stimulated AR activity. Our results provide unique in vivo insights to the multidimensional cell-type-specific interactions between AR and coregulators.

     neurogenic differentiation 2 Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family   Shannan HoSui TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	    NDRF, in combination with E47, has been shown to activate IP3R1 gene expression via E-box motifs present in the box-I enhancer (EMSA and luciferase reporters). The C-terminal domain of NDRF is the activation domain, as demonstrated by deletion analysis and luciferase reporter gene experiments.	  8816493    DNA Binding; Transactivation Human	      Medium	      Expression vectors driving the human neuroD1 and neuroD2 coding regions from a simian cytomegalovirus promoter, pCS2-hND1 and pCS2-hND2 were constructed, and the activity of neuroD1 and neuroD2 on reporter constructs cotransfected into P19 cells was assayed. Other member of the neuroD family have been shown to bind to consensus E-box sequences in vitro. In vitro gel shift assays demonstrated that NeuroD1 and neuroD2 can bind to an oligonucleotide containing the core E-box CACCTG as a heterodimer with an E-protein (not shown here). The authors tested the ability of NeuroD1/2 to activate transcription of a simple reporter construct composed of multimerized E-box with the same core sequence and the minimal promoter from the thymidine kinase gene driving the luciferase gene, p4RTKluc. Transfection of either pCS2-hND1 or pCS2-hND2 modestly increased the level of activity from p4RTK-luc in P19 cells, increasing the activity between two- and fourfold. Additional reporter constructs were tested in P19 cells to determine whether neuroD1 and neuroD2 had different transcriptional activation potentials. The ability of pCS2-hND1 and pCS2-hND2 to transactivate a luciferase reporter construct driven by a 760-bp core promoter of the GAP-43 gene (pGAP43-luciferase), a neuron-specific promoter construct which is upregulated in vivo in postmitotic, terminally differentiating neurons was tested. In contrast to the simple E-box driven reporter, pCS2-hND1 did not show significant transactivation of the pGAP43-luciferase, while pCS2-hND2 induced expression from this construct by approximately fourfold over the basal activity.

																																																																																																	      		 		   	       			      	       10098882	     Co-activation; DNA Binding; Transactivation    Mouse Medium	 In this study, DNA-binding assays, transient luciferase assay,s and in situ hybridization for NDRF suggest that NDRF functions as a positive regulatory factor for IP3R1 gene expression in the CNS. NeuroD-like factors were detected in box-I-related nucleoprotein complexes formed by brain nuclear extract (EMSA and western blotting for NeuroD-like proteins). To confirm that NDRF binds to the box-I element of the IP3R1 gene, EMSA using recombinant NDRF protein was performed. E47 itself bound the box-I sequence weakly; NDRF alone did not bind stably to box-I; but NDRF markedly enhances the DNA-binding of E47 through heterodimerization. Mutation of the E-box sequence in box-I descreased binding affinity of NDRF/E47. Activation function of NDRF was assayed using cotransfection experiments in PC12h cells, which express low but significant levels of IP3R1. The reporter plasmid contained the luceriferase gene under the control of the IP3R1 promoter. Cotranfection with NDRF resulted in ~5-fold activation.

      		     		    		 		    	  		 10871374	Co-activation; Transactivation		 Mouse	 Medium	C-AD, the transcriptional activation domain of NDRF, was identified in the C-terminal region by performing transient luciferase reporter assays using various effector plasmids expressing GAL4 DBD/NDRF fusion proteins. Consistent with previous reports, competitive EMSA showed that E47 bound the box-I sequence weakly. Addition of NDRF markedly enhanced specific DNA-binding of E47, whereas NDRF alone did not bind the probe DNA.To investigate the role of C-AD in E-box-directed transcriptional activation, luciferase reporter gene assay were performed. PC12 cells were transfected with an expression vector producing wild-type NDRF (1�383) or its C-AD-truncated version (1�315). The IP3R1 promoter was stimulated ~5-fold by co-transfection of the wild-type NDRF, while it was activated only 2-fold by the C-AD-truncated NDRF. Since NDRF enhanced DNA-binding ability of E47, we examined the effects of the transcriptional activation function of class A proteins using a mutant E47 (473�651) that lacks its activation domain(s). Transcriptional activation functions of both wild-type and mutant NDRF were repressed by co-expression of E47 (473�651), while no repression was observed by co-expression of wild-type E47 (1�651).

		    		Stuart Lithwick	     TF Gene  DNA-Binding: non-sequence-specific     GeneID: 18019Referring to PMID: 15684054NFATc2 may be a transcription factor, which stimulates IL-21 promoter activity, and binds to the IL-21 proximal promoter. In unstimulated and PMA+I stimulated mouse EL4 cell lines, expression of a IL-21 promoter-reporter construct increases 40-fold and 600-fold respectively when cotransfected with NFATc2. Also, NFATc2 interacts with the IL-21 promoter in Th2 cells but not Th1 cells as demonstrated by ChIP. However, the specific binding site for NFATc2 within the IL-21 promoter still needs to be determined, and this is important information with regards to identifying NFATc2 as a transcription factor.	15684054	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Mouse	Medium	GeneID:  18019	Referring to PMID: 15684054NFATc2 Activates IL-21 promoter activity and binds to the upstream DNA region. Mouse EL4 cells were transfected with IL-21-luc alone or with anexpression vector for NFATc2, and the luciferase activity of bothunstimulated and PMA-I stimulated cells was measured. Withoutstimulation, IL-21-luc reporter activity was induced 40-fold relative tobasal activity in the presence of exogenous NFATc2.PMA-stimulation of NFATc2-transfected cells increased thelevel of IL-21-luc reporter activity to nearly 600x relative to basal levels,suggesting that although NFATc2 could by itself transactivatethe IL-21 promoter, other factors that are induced duringPMA-I treatment, such as AP-1 family members, can furtheraugment promoter activity.NFATc2 binds the IL-21 Proximal Promoter in Vivo. Using ChIP experiments on CD4-T cells under Th1 or Th2 cell conditions for 14 days, NFATc2 was found to bind the IL-21 promoter in Th2 cells but not Th1 cells.

    	       		      	 Stuart Lithwick     TF Gene		DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	   GeneID: 18021Referring to PMIDs: 7650004, 15173172Mouse NFATc3 is likely a transcription factor, which binds to the NFAT-binding site sequence found upstream of mouse IL-2 and increases the activity of the mouse Sfptd promoter. As demonstrated in PMID 15173172 by electromobility shift assay, mouse NFATc3 binds in a sequence specific manner to the NFATc binding site sequence found upstream of mouse IL-2. As well, as demonstrated in PMID 7650004, NFATc3 activates mouse Sfptd promoter activity. Cotransfection of NFATc3 expression plasmids with Sftpd promoter-luciferase construct plasmids leads to increases in promoter activity.   7650004 Co-activation; DNA Binding      Human; Mouse     Medium	 GeneID:18021Referring to PMID: 7650004NFATc3 may be a transcription factor that binds to the NFAT binding site present within the mouse IL-2 promoter. In EMSA assays nuclear extracts from COS cells transfected with expression vectors encoding NFATc1, NFATc2, or NFATc3 were incubated with probe, which included the NFAT binding site within the mouse IL-2 promoter. Upon lowering the concentration of nonspecific competitor poly(dI-dC), NFATc3 binding was observed and the gel shift could be eliminated by adding unlabeled IL-2 NFAT site competitive inhibitor. The observed gel shift  was also eliminated by adding excess unlabeled AP probe, indicating that NFATc3 may bind to this DNA site in complex with AP1-related proteins. The concentration of nonspecific competitor used to demonstrate NFATc3 binding to the IL-2 NFAT site in COS extracts overexpressing NFATc3 was significantly lower than that required to obtain specific binding of the endogenous NFAT complex to this site in primary cell extracts. Thus, the IL-2 NFAT site most likely does not represent a physiologic DNA binding site for NFATc3.

18030		 nuclear factor, interleukin 3, regulated	     Zipper-Type Group/Leucine Zipper Family	 Shannan HoSui	      TF Gene		 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific			      E4BP4, a bZIP transcription factor, has been shown to have both repressor and enhancer activity using reporter gene assays. Direct binding to a ATTACGTCTG consensus sequence was shown using EMSA and DNase footprinting.       7565758	    DNA Binding; Transactivation   Human	      Medium	 To define the transcriptional regulatory activity of NF-IL3A on the IL-3 promoter, transient transfections into MLA144 cells were performed. Introduction of the NF-IL3A BC12 expression plasmid into resting MLA144 T cells increased the CAT activity generated by the -315 and -173 plasmids 5.2- and 5.0-fold, respectively, compared with that generated by the BC12 expression vector alone. No significant change in the promoter activity of the -61 plasmid, which lacks the A region sequences, was seen. Introduction of 3-bp substitutions into the NF-IL3A consensus binding sequence eliminated responsiveness to NF-IL3A. Similarly, cotransfection of the NF-IL3A BC12 plasmid had no effect on the enhancerless pTE2 plasmid, but it activated the pTE2 plasmid containing two copies of the A region sequences approximately fivefold. These experiments demonstrate that the GTC nucleotides in the NF-IL3A consensus binding sequence (ATTACGTCTG) in the A region are required for responsiveness to NFIL3A. Specific binding of NF-IL3A to IL-3 promoter sequences was confirmed by competitive EMSA and DNase footprinting.

																																																																																																																																																																																																																					 		 	 	 	     			     		 10074173      DNA Binding; Transactivation	      Human		 Medium	      The binding specificity of E4BP4 was examined by competitive EMSA using a recombinant E4BP4 protein obtained by fusion of the E4BP4 open reading frame with that of the 1.3S subunit of the Proprionibacterium shermanii transcarboxylase. The results indicate that the sequence from nt 1650 to 1662 in box alpha  was the binding site for E4BP4. This segment contains the sequence cTTACaTAAg (the lowercase letters represent the sequence which is different from the consensus E4BP4 binding sequence), which resembled the consensus E4BP4 binding sequence (A/G)T(G/T)A(T/C)GTAA(T/C) (12).The binding specificity of overexpressed E4BP4 protein was examined in HuH-7 cells in transient-transfection assays. Total cell lysates from untransfected and transfected cells were obtained for Western and gel shift experiments. Two forms of E4BP4 were detected with anti-E4BP4 antiserum in pf:E4BP4-transfected cells. Box alpha binding activity was present in both untransfected cells and cells transfected with pf:E4BP4 or empty vector. In the nuclear extracts obtained from pf:E4BP4 transfectants, a supershift of box alpha  binding activity by anti-FLAG and anti-E4BP4 antibodies was observed. This supershift was not seen with a control preimmune serum. These results indicated that E4BP4 could indeed bind to the box alpha  sequence. They also showed that E4BP4 is not a major component of endogenous box alpha binding proteins. Moreover, inclusion of unlabeled competing oligonucleotides in molar excess showed that wild-type box alpha  and the EF sequences could effectively abolish the box alpha  binding activity that was supershifted with anti-FLAG antibody. Identical results were obtained with another E4BP4-transfected differentiated human hepatoma cell line, HepG2.A single copy of the box alpha  sequence in an upstream position stimulates the transcription of the HBV basal core promoter in both HepG2 and HuH-7 cells (68). To examine the effect of E4BP4 on box alpha , a CAT reporter plasmid containing an upstream box alpha sequence was cotransfected with pf:E4BP4 or pFLAG-CMV2 vector in HepG2 and HuH-7 cells. Coexpression of E4BP4 reduced the CAT activity by 35- and 14-fold in HepG2 and HuH-7 cells, respectively. Cotransfection with pFLAG-CMV2, which had no insert, had no significant effect.

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				18045	   nuclear transcription factor-Y beta	       	   Gwenael Breard      TF Gene	    Basal Transcription Factor	The eukaryotic transcription factor NF-Y (also termed CBF) specifically recognizes the regulatory CCAAT element found in either orientation in the proximal and distal enhancer regions of many genes. In higher eukaryotes, this element is found in about 30% of the promoters, preferentially in the -60/-100 region, and analysis of various CCAAT boxes showed that specific flanking sequences are required for efficient binding.	12401788	TF PPI	Other	Not Selected	The heterotrimeric transcription factor NF-Y recognizes with high specificity and affinity the CCAAT regulatory element that is widely represented in promoters and enhancer regions. The CCAAT box acts in concert with neighboring elements, and its bending by NF-Y is thought to be a major mechanism required for transcription activation. We have solved the structure of the NF-YC/NF-YB subcomplex of NF-Y, which shows that the core domains of both proteins interact through histone fold motifs. This histone-like pair is closely related to the H2A/H2B and NC2alpha/NC2beta families, with features that are both common to this class of proteins and unique to NF-Y. The structure together with the modeling of the nonspecific interaction of NF-YC/NF-YB with DNA and the full NF-Y/CCAAT box complex highlight important structural features that account for different and possibly similar biological functions of the transcriptional regulators NF-Y and NC2.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				18046	   nuclear transcription factor-Y gamma		   Other Alpha-Helix Group/NF-Y CCAAT-Binding Protein Family	Rob Sladek     TF Gene	     DNA-Binding: sequence-specific		The CCAAT box is a widespread element found in promoters and enhancers. Nuclear factor Y (NFY), also termed CCAAT-binding factor (CBF), is a ubiquitous heterotrimeric protein containing NFYA (189903), NFYB (189904), and NFYC. NFYB and NFYC must interact and dimerize for NFYA association and DNA binding, most notably to Y-box elements such as CCAAT in major histocompatibility (MHC) class II promoters (see MHC2TA; 600005), to occur. 30 MEDLINE Neighbors

   18504			 paired box gene 2  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family			    Shannan HoSui      TF Gene		 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific				Pax2 has been shown to bind to the promoter regions of several genes, including GDNF and SFRP2, and activate transcription.  Pax2 activation can further be enhanced by phosphorylation, as shown by CAT reporter assays. Specific DNA-binding has been shown by EMSA.	11700324  Transactivation   Human	Medium	To assess the effects of Pax2 phosphorylation on the transactivation potential, a reporter plasmid containing five copies of the PRS4 Pax2b binding sequence upstream of a minimal promoter and the chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT) gene was used. Using a fixed amount of Pax2b plasmid and increasing amounts of MEKK1, Pax2-dependent reporter activation increased dramatically with as little as 50 ng of MEKK1 expression plasmid. Pax2 transfection can stimulate the reporter plasmid activity by 8-10-fold. This increased to more than 50-fold by co-transfection of 200 ng of MEKK1 expression plasmid. In the absence of Pax2, MEKK1 had no effect on the expression of the reporter. Furthermore, a kinase-deficient MEKK1 construct showed only a slight increase at the highest doses. Pax2-dependent transactivation was also enhanced in the presence of Wnt expression plasmids. Expression of Wnt4, Wnt11, and Wnt7a all generated a 2-3-fold increase in Pax2-dependent activation of the reporter gene. Whereas Wnt gene expression alone had no effect on CAT activity in the absence of Pax2. As reported previously (3), deletion of the transactivation domain reduced Pax2-dependent activation.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																	    				 	    	    		     		       11731455			    DNA Binding; Transactivation	 Mouse	      Strong					To determine if Pax2 can bind and transactivate the GDNF gene directly, potential GDNF regulatory sequences were examined for Pax2-binding activity and Pax2-dependent transcription activation potential. A mouse BAC library was used to identify GDNF exon 1-containing fragments that were then fused to the reporter gene, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase (CAT). Sequences spanning 2.4 or 4.2 kb upstream from a unique BamHI site in exon 1 were indistinguishable in their ability to activate reporter gene expression in a Pax2-dependent manner. We thus focused on the smaller construct, p2.4-CAT. Using increasing amounts of Pax2 expression vectors, p2.4-CAT was activated 20- to 30-fold in response to Pax2b and approximately 10- to 15-fold in response to Pax2a.A combination of EMSA and DNAseI footprint analyses was used to map potential Pax2-binding sites within the 2.4 kb region that demonstrated Pax2-dependent activation of the reporter. Fragments spanning the entire region were isolated and used in gel shift experiments with increasing amounts of recombinant Pax2-PD. In addition, total digests of the 2.4 kb region were subject to gel shift analysis to ascertain if specific fragments could be identified that showed an increase in electrophoretic mobility. From these initial digests at least two binding sites were identified. To map the Pax2-PD binding sequences more precisely, DNAseI footprinting was carried out using the corresponding fragments for PBS1 and PBS2. However, only the fragment corresponding to PBS2 gave a recognizable DNAseI footprint, most probably owing to better binding efficiency. A double-stranded oligonucleotide corresponding to the DNAseI footprint of PBS2 was used in gel shift experiments to confirm binding specificity. Within the fragment spanning PBS1, a closely related sequence to PBS2 was identified and oligonucleotides made against this region also bound Pax2. Binding to the PBS1 and PBS2 oligonucleotides could be inhibited with increasing amounts of unlabeled competitor DNA.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																											       				    		 			 	      						   14561758  DNA Binding; Transactivation	Mouse	 Medium		To examine the ability of Pax2 to bind directly to and regulate the Sfrp2 locus, two overlapping Sfrp2 genomic clones spanning more than 13 kb were screened for Pax2-binding sites using a protein/DNA pull-down assay. Unlabeled competitor DNAs from the high affinity Pax2-binding sequence H2A were added to test for specificity. In all cases, the pulled down fragments were competed out with an excess of unlabeled H2A Pax2-binding sequence. The Pax2-paired domain specifically bound strongly to two fragments that were subcloned, sequenced, and analyzed further by electrophoretic mobility shift experiments. They mapped within the potential regulatory region upstream of the Sfrp2 translation initiation site and both bound recombinant Pax2 protein in the region spanning -411 to -210, mapping around the DNaseI hypersensitive site II that is prominent only in the 28Pax2 cells. The ability of Pax2 to activate the Sfrp2 promoter region was examined in a heterologous system using transient transfections. The plasmid p2.8PX-CAT fused a 2.8-kb PstI-XhoI upstream of the CAT reporter gene. Transfection into HEK293 or NIH3T3 cells together with increasing amounts of a Pax2 expression plasmid reveals an ability of Pax2 to transactivate directly this promoter region. Activation of reporter gene expression was 2-fold in the presence of Pax2b protein. Although this was not as robust as other Pax2-responsive elements described, the activation was statistically significant and reproducible.

     18509	  paired box gene 7	     Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family		 Shannan HoSui TF Gene	   DNA-Binding: sequence-specific; Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding Pax7 was originally described as a member of the paired-homeobox gene family. It has been shown that the function of Pax7 partially overlaps with the paralogous Pax3 gene during development, which might explain the lack of a discernable phenotype in Pax7 mutant mice during somite formation. Both genes strongly stimulate cell proliferation in various tissues.	15688409	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Human; Mouse	Strong	EMSA was used to characterize the DNA binding properties of the 6 wild-type PAX3 and PAX7 isoforms (PAX3/Q+, PAX3/Q-, PAX7/Q+GL+, PAX7/Q+GL-, PAX7/Q-GL+ and PAX7/Q-GL-). Each isoform formed a single shifted band with 32P-labeled P6CON or PRS-9 probe representative of the DNA-protein complex. The specificity of the complexes was further confirmed by the fact that the shifted bands disappeared when unlabeled competitor probes were included in the binding reaction at 50- or 200-fold molar excesses over labeled probes, whereas the DNA-protein complexes remained undisturbed when excess unlabeled nonspecific competitor was added. PAX7/Q-GL- exhibited the highest binding affinity, which is 4.7-fold higher than that of PAX7/Q+GL+ form.Reporter assays were performed to investigate the functional differences among the various isoforms. The ability of PAX7-FKHR to transactivate the expression of reporter plasmids 6xCD19-E1b-CAT and 6xPRS-9-E1b-CAT, which have 6 copies of the class I CD19 or class II PRS-9 binding site upstream of the TATA element of the E1b promoter was examined. Among the PAX7-FKHR isoforms, Q-GL- showed the highest transcriptional activation with the 6xCD19-E1b-CAT reporter (about 50-fold of that of the Q+GL+ form), followed by Q+GL- and Q-GL+ isoforms (about 2-3 fold of that of the Q+GL+ form).

cooperatively bind DNA. This interaction depends on amino-terminal sequences in PBX1 that are not present in the oncoprotein E2a-PBX1: consequently E2a-PBX1 is unable to bind DNA as a MEIS1 heterodimer. 																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																															       				     			    		      			    	     	       12114521		  Transactivation Human	       Weak		    "Although most studies of progesterone receptors (PR) and their two isoforms, PR-A and PR-B, focus on transcriptional stimulation, the receptors exhibit important inhibitory properties. Autoinhibition refers to an inhibitory function located in the PR N terminus, whose deletion increases transcriptional activity at least 6-10-fold. Transrepression refers to the ability of PR-A to suppress the transcriptional activity of PR-B and other nuclear receptors, including estrogen receptors. Self-squelching refers to the observation in transient transfection assays that increasing receptor concentrations paradoxically decrease transcriptional activity. Using a series of N-terminal deletion mutants constructed in both PR isoforms, we have mapped their autoinhibitory and transrepressor activities to a small ubiquitin-like modifier (SUMO-1) protein consensus-binding motif."
