																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																						       18986	      POU domain, class 2, transcription factor 1	  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family  Jared Roach     TF Gene  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific  Also known as Oct-1. This is a well-known TF.  1980478	    DNA Binding	Unknown	   Strong    "The ubiquitous octamer-binding protein oct-1 contains a POU domain required for DNA binding, which can be subdivided into a POU-specific domain and a POU homeo domain. We have overproduced the POU domain and the POU homeo domain in a vaccinia expression system, purified both polypeptides to near homogeneity, and compared their DNA-binding properties. In contrast to the POU domain, the homeo domain protects only part of the octamer sequence in the Ad2 origin against breakdown by DNase I or hydroxyl radicals. Analysis of purine contacts by DMS and DEPC interference assays shows that the Ad2 octamer can be divided into two regions: one that is recognized both by the POU domain and the homeo domain in an identical fashion, and one that is only recognized by the POU domain. This suggests that the POU-specific domain is responsible for the additional contacts located at one side of the octamer. In agreement with this, mutating the first 3 nucleotides (ATG) of the octamer affected binding by the POU domain but not by the homeo domain. The apparent binding affinities to different octamer sites were compared. The homeo domain binds 600-fold less efficiently to the canonical octamer sequence (ATGCAAAT) than the POU domain. The difference is only sevenfold for the Ad2 octamer, whereas both Kd values are almost identical for the HSV ICP4 TAATGARAT motif. Both the POU and homeo domains recognize target sequences for mammalian homeo box proteins. We conclude that the octamer can act as a bipartite recognition sequence for oct-1 and that the POU-specific domain contributes to the binding affinity, as well as to the specificity, by providing additional contacts."

Binding	  Unknown     Strong   "The Oct-3/4 is a transcriptional factor expressed rather specifically in inner cell mass and embryonic ectoderm during early embryogenesis in mammals. During the course of characterizing the regulatory element of embryonic transcriptional coactivator UTF1 which is one of the downstream genes of Oct-3/4, we have found that Oct-3/4, but not other Octamer factors, shows unique DNA binding specificity, being able to bind to variant Octamer sequence (5'-ACTAGCAT-3') present in UTF1 regulatory element. Here, we have determined the DNA binding property of Oct-3/4 in a systematic manner using all possible one point mutants of Octamer sequence as well as completely random sequences. These analyses led to the identification of nine distinct nucleotide sequences including the one (5'-ACTAGCAT-3') present in UTF1 regulatory element which serves rather as specific binding site for the Oct-3/4. Moreover, we show that, at least, one of the newly identified sequences, 5'-ATCAGCAT-3', exhibits a transcriptional stimulating activity equivalent to that of the variant Octamer sequence present in the UTF1 regulatory region in embryonic stem cells in a pluripotent-state specific manner. "

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				     			      	       	     		   	12847522      Transactivation  Mouse	   Strong Hypertension and diabetes are common side effects of glucocorticoid treatment. To determine whether PPAR-alpha mediates these sequelae, authors treated chronically with dexamethasone mice deficient in low-density lipoprotein receptor (Ldlr -/-), with (Ppara +/+) or without (Ppara -/-) PPAR-alpha. Ppara +/+, but not Ppara -/-, mice developed hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hypertension. The Ppara +/+, but not Ppara -/-, mice developed hypertension. Adenoviral reconstitution of PPAR-alpha in the livers of nondiabetic, normotensive, dexamethasone-treated Ppara -/- mice induced hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and increased gluconeogenic gene expression. It also increased blood pressure, renin activity, sympathetic nervous activity, and renal sodium retention. Human hepatocytes treated with dexamethasone and a PPAR-alpha agonist showed induction of PPARA and gluconeogenic gene expression. These results identified hepatic activation of PPAR-alpha as a mechanism underlying glucocorticoid-induced insulin resistance

      		 	     	Stuart Lithwick	       TF Gene		   DNA-Binding: sequence-specific  Rax is likely a transcription factor given that it binds to the upstream PCE-1 element of the mouse arrestin gene and activates the expression of the both the arrestin and IRBP promoters when cotransfected. The PCE-1 element of the mouse arrestin gene was shown to be bound by protein when incubated with human GST-RX fusion protein. Supershifts using anti-GST antibody further indicated that the GST-RX fusion protein was the factor that was binding to the PCE-1 site. Also, cotransfection of RX with mouse arrestin-lacZ and IRBP-lacZ constructs in 293 cell lines led to increases in reporter activity.	10625658	DNA Binding	Human; Mouse	Strong	GeneID: 19434Referring to PMID: 10625658Rax is likely a transcription factor that binds to the upstream PCE-1 element of the mouse arrestin gene. Using EMSA, mobility shift is observed when the m-PCE-1 element is incubated with GST-Rax protein. This shift is competed significantly by a 40-fold molar excess of unlabeled m-PCE-1 competitor, but only slightly by a 200-fold molar excess of unlabeled m-OTX competitor. The bound protein was also identified to be Rax by supershift assays. EMSA was also performed using purified GST-Rax and oligonucleotide probes containing the identical mouse (-21 CAATTAG -15) and bovine upstream (-1830 CAATTAG -1824) PCE-1 site. These oligonucleotides bound strongly to GST-Rax to form complexes (Fig. 6, lanes 1-10) suggesting that the PCE-1 core consensus (CAATTA(G/A)) was an essential binding element and the flanking sequence contributed minimally to the observed binding activity. Rax may activate arrestin promoter activity. Human Rax and the mouse arrestin promoter/CAT reporter constructs are cotransfected into human embryonic kidney (293) cells which exhibit no endogenous Rax expression. Co-transfection of human Rax stimulates promoter activity reaching 6.4-fold induction.

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																				  19883	     RAR-related orphan receptor alpha	Zinc-coordinating Group/Hormone-nuclear Receptor Family	Jared Roach  TF Gene   DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	Nucelar hormone receptor.	7926749	DNA Binding	Unknown	Strong	"Three isoforms of a novel member of the steroid hormone nuclear receptor superfamily related to the retinoic acid receptors have been identified. The three isoforms, referred to as ROR alpha 1, ROR alpha 2, and ROR alpha 3, share common DNA- and putative ligand-binding domains but are characterized by distinct amino-terminal domains generated by alternative RNA processing. An exon encoding a functionally important subregion of the amino-terminal domain of the ROR alpha 2 isoform resides on the opposite strand of a cytochrome c-processed pseudogene. Binding site selection using in vitro-synthesized proteins reveals that the ROR alpha 1 and ROR alpha 2 isoforms bind DNA as monomers to hormone response elements composed of a 6-bp AT-rich sequence preceding a half-site core motif PuGGTCA (RORE). However, ROR alpha 1 and ROR alpha 2 display different binding specificities: ROR alpha 1 binds to and constitutively activates transcription from a large subset of ROREs, whereas ROR alpha 2 recognizes ROREs with strict specificity and displays weaker transcriptional activity. The differential DNA-binding activity of each isoform maps to their respective amino-terminal domains. Whereas truncation of the amino-terminal domain diminishes the ability of ROR alpha 1 to bind DNA, a similar deletion relaxes ROR alpha 2-binding specificity to that displayed by ROR alpha 1. Remarkably, transfer of the entire amino-terminal region of ROR alpha 1 or amino-terminal deletion of ROR alpha 2 confers RORE-binding specificities to heterologous receptors. These results demonstrate that the amino-terminal domain and the zinc finger region work in concert to confer high affinity and specific DNA-binding properties to the ROR isoforms and suggest a novel strategy to control DNA-binding activity of nuclear receptors."

sequence-specific     RXRa is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays key roles in a variety of physiological phenomenon either as a homodimer or as a heterodimer with a wide range of other members of the nuclear receptor superfamily. Transactivation activity has been confirmed by luceriferase report gene assays using RXRa-specific binding sites, or binding sites specific to RXRa cofactors.    7838715	DNA Binding; TF PPI Mouse  Medium     ARF6 was previously identified as a key regulator of the tissue-specific adipocyte P2 (aP2) enhancer. ARF6 was purified from HIB-1 B nuclear extract by a combination of conventional and sequence-specific DNA affinity chromotography (EMSA was used to confirm specific binding to ARX6 sites). Chemical sequencing and mass spectral analysis of tryptic peptides derived from the purified polypeptides identifies the ARF6 complex as a heterodimer of the retinoid X receptor a (RXRa) and the murine peroxisome proliferator activated receptor y (PPARy).
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																											       		      	       	 	  			     		       			     15544927 Co-activation; DNA Binding; Transactivation	     Human  Strong   The authors report the identification of two novel splice forms of RXRa. The predicted protein products of RXR&#945;2 and RXR&#945;3 lack the N-terminal 27 and 97 amino acid residues in the region containing AF-1 of RXRa1. Since AF-1 activates transcription either by itself, depending on the cell and promoter context, or synergistically with AF-2 in a ligand-dependent manner, we examined whether the products of RXRa2 and RXR&#945;3 can function as a nuclear receptor and further whether they function differently from the product of RXRa1. The products of RXRa2 and RXRa3 were confirmed to be able to activate transcription and responded to ligand dose-dependently, as shown by dual luciferase reporter gene assay using RXRE as a response element and the RXR agonist LG100268. LG100268 is a highly RXR-selective synthetic retinoid analogs and is known to activate RXR�RXR homodimer as well as RXR heterodimers such as RXR�PPAR&#947; and RXR�LXR [27] and [28]. There were no significant differences in the ligand dose�response curves between RXR&#945;1 and RXR&#945;2 or RXR&#945;3. A major role of RXR seems to be to function as a coreceptor by forming a heterodimer with other nuclear receptors. Therefore, transactivation by the PPAR&#947;2�RXR&#945; heterodimer, using PPRE as a response element, was tested. As in the homodimer system, there were no significant differences in transactivation ability and ligand response between RXR&#945;1 and RXR&#945;2 or RXR&#945;3.

Binding	Mouse	  Strong		EMSA with IR0 element of mouse TR2-11 gene shows retardation only when both RAR and RXR are incubated together, with supershifting occurring when anti-RAR Ab is added. Mutation of 5' half-site or 3' half-site of IR0 results in drastic decrease in DNA binding, and the complex can be competed out by unlabeled complementary DNA fragment. co-factor binding	 Ncor1 is a nuclear receptor corepressor. It is first known to bind unliganded nuclear receptors (RAR, TR).Ncor1 was also shown to recruit TF, inactivating them through this interaction.It is part of a protein complex including HDACs and other proteins binding histones. It is thus thought that this complexe acts through the binding to chromatin and deacetylation of histones, maintaining the chromatin in an inactive state.Ncor1 doesn't seem to bind directly to chromatin.  11997503	TF PPI	    Mouse  Strong    Ncor1 binds to the transcription factor B-Myb (mammalian two-hybrid assay and co-IP in 293T cells).Inhibition of the repression function of N-CoR and SMRT releases B-Myb transactivation activity.       20230	   special AT-rich sequence binding protein 1  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Homeodomain Family   Tim Hughes		       TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific			 Satb1 was initially characterized as a protein that binds to Matrix Attachment Region sequences (PMID: 1505028) and most of the literature on the gene and its product is in regard to this role.  The DNA-binding specificity is well-studied (PMID: 1505028, PMID: 8114718) and the DNA-binding domain has been mapped (PMID: 8114718) and overlaps approximately with what is apparently a homeodomain that was not evident when the protein was initially characterized.  The initial papers (PMID: 1505028, PMID: 8114718) elaborated upon the structural features of the binding sequence; however, the primary sequence does resemble a classical homeobox.  A SATB1 transgene reduces transcription of a stably-transfected MAR-containing reporter (PMID: 9340009).	1505028	DNA Binding	Human	Not Selected	Satb1 was initially characterized as a protein that binds to Matrix Attachment Region sequences.

 transcriptional regulator, SIN3A (yeast)			    Debra Fulton	   TF Gene   Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	     Sin3A is a transcription factor. It binds HDAC1/HDAC2 complex by coimmunoprecipitation assays and potentiates the inhibitory function of HDAC1 on the hLHR promoter reporter gene by cotransfection in reporter gene assays.	12091390	Other; TF PPI	Human	Strong	Transfection of wild type hLHR promoter/reporter gene construct (WT) and the promoterless vector plasmid (Basic) into JAR cells proceeded with TSA incubation (TSA is a specific HDAC inhibitor) shows a dose-dependent activation of the hLHR promoter activity by TSA demonstrating that  transcription of the hLHR gene is subject to modulation through chromatin modification related to histone acetylation and deacetylation. RT-PCR analyses of total RNA isolated from the JAR cells treated with or without TSA demonstrates that the endogenous expression of the hLHR gene governed by its natural promoter is regulated by TSA.Acetylated H3 and H4 accumulates only in TSA-treated JAR cells and is predominantly bound to the human LHR gene promoter (by Western blot analyses using antibodies against the aceylated form of histone H3 or H4 and chromatin immunoprecipitation - precipitated with antibodies against acetylated H3, H4, or RNA polymerase II).The Sp1-1 site is critical for TSA-mediated activation/derepression of hLHR Gene by reporter gene analyses utilizing the hLHR wild type promoter (WT) and its various mutant constructs.Binding of Sp1/Sp3 to the Sp1-1 site was not affected by TSA (by EMSA/supershifts).Coimmunoprecipitation assays reveal an association of histone deacetylases HDAC1 and HDAC2 with the Sp1-1 complex. Direct association between mSin3A and either HDAC1 or HDAC2 is shown by co-precipitation by both HDAC antibodies but mSin3A is not revealed in the presence of Sp1 or Sp3 antibody, indicating that there is no direct protein-protein interaction between mSin3A and the Sp1/Sp3 factors.Cotransfection of mSin3A with HDAC1 in JAR cells signficantly enhanced the repression of hLHR promoter activity by HDAC1 (to 70%). However, cotransfection of mSin3A and HDAC2 does not cause further inhibition of hLHR promoter activity when compared with that elicited by HDAC2 alone suggesting that mSin3A is a corepressor protein that potentiates the inhibitory function of HDAC1.

   20852	    signal transducer and activator of transcription 6	    Other/Stat Protein Family	   Rob Sladek	   TF Gene     DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	  Stat6 was identified by searching an EST database for transcripts homologous to known conserved Stat protein motifs.Gel shift assays performed with IL4-treated human Kit225 T cells showed a single retarded band when incubated with a probe sequence containing the GAS-like element from the human immunoglobulin C-epsilon gene: antibody supershift studies confirmed that Stat6 was contained in retarded complex.Gel shift assays performed with IL4-treated HeLa cells showed a single retarded band when incubated with a probe sequence containing the human IL4R gene promoter IFN-gamma-activated site (GAS) in gel shift assays. Participation of STAT6 in the retarded complex was demonstrated by antibody supershift.Cotransfection studies showed that recombinant STAT6 activated a reporter construct containing containing three copies of the the IL-4R target site following treament of transiently transfected HeLa cells with IL-4. STAT6 transcriptional activity in this system could be reduced by deleting residues in the protein's amino- or carboxy-terminus. A reporter plasmid containing a single copy of the IRF-1 GAS site (IRF-1 GAS-TK-Luc) was activated in STAT6-transfected HeLa cells following treatment with IFN-gamma.	7760829	DNA Binding	Mouse	Strong	Stat6 was identified by searching an EST database for transcripts homologous to known conserved Stat protein motifs.Gel shift assays performed with IL4-treated human Kit225 T cells showed a single retarded band when incubated with a probe sequence containing the GAS-like element from the human immunoglobulin C-epsilon gene: antibody supershift studies confirmed that Stat6 was contained in retarded complex.

    20893	       basic helix-loop-helix domain containing, class B2	    Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family	Shannan HoSui	  TF Gene  Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	      Dec1 is a basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor involved in regulating the circadian rhythms in mammals. Dec1 and Dec2  repress Clock/Bmal1-induced transactivation of the mouse Per1 promoter through direct protein-protein interactions with Bmal1 and/or competition from E-box elements. The Dec1 binding site, CACGTG, is a class B E-box element, and was identified via a PCR-based binding site selection protocol and EMSA  12297495	   DNA Binding		       Mouse	  Strong  The paper identifies Stra13 as a transcriptional repressor protein that functions to regulate E-box elements through cross-interference with E-box-binding transcriptional activators that bind such sites and through direct transcriptional repression from the class B E-box and related sites. The Stra13 binding site, CACGTG, which is a class B E-box element, was identified via a PCR-based binding site selection protocol and EMSA. Competitive repression by Stra13 through class B (CACGTG) E-box elements was demonstrated in COS-7 cells or HC11 cells using luciferase reporter assays.

    		       	     		      	     		       		    12397359	DNA Binding; TF PPI    Mouse	Strong	Both Dec1 and Dec2 suppressed Clock/Bmal1-induced activation of Per1 promoter in a dose-dependent manner as reported by a luciferase assay. Gel retardation assays show that both mouse Dec1 and mouse Dec2 bound to mouse Per1 proximal E-box elements. The binding was specific to an E-box, because excess dose of unlabelled E-box but not mutant E-box inhibited the binding.   Yeast two-hybrid assay revealed that both Dec1 and Dec2 bound stereospecifically to Bmal1. Dec1 and Dec2 lacking the C-terminal regions were able to bind to Bmal1 as did the full-length Decs, but those lacking the amino terminal failed to bind, suggesting the bHLH is the responsible site.

factor ( DRB being the transcription inhibitor 5,6-dichloro-1-beta-D-ribofuranosylbenzimidazole).DSIF is a dual regulator of transcription that stimulates, or, when cooperating with negative Spt4 and Spt5 are also thought to be involved in mRNA capping, homologous DNA recombination, and transcription-coupled DNA repair.    9450929   Other   Human	 Medium	  DSIF (Spt4 + Spt5)  induces the arrest of elongating RNA Pol II in the absence of DRB, indicating that DSIF works as a negative elongation factor (purified DSIF in a partially reconstituted transcription system).DSIF can stimulate transcription elongation under certain conditions (in vitro transcription system).

      20937		  suppressor of variegation 3-9 homolog 1 (Drosophila)	  	    Debra Fulton   TF Gene    Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding   Suv39h1 cooperates with Smad1 (by co-immunoprecipitation) to repress activation of an MCK promoter reporter gene. 15107829	 Co-activation Mouse  Medium	     A mouse embryonic E9.5 library screen with MH2 domains of Smad5 identifies the Suv39h2 protein. Co-immunoprecipitation assays using various flag-tagged Smad proteins together with Suv39h1 demonstrate that Suv39h proteins interact specifically with Smad1 and Smad5.Different constructs of myc-tagged Suv39h1 in co-immunoprecipitation assays demonstrate that Smad1 (and presumably Smad5) binds to an internal region of Suv39h1 molecule.       T-cell acute lymphocytic leukemia 1	Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family Rob Sladek  TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	Consensus DNA binding sites for a TAL1/E47 heterodimer were identified by cyclic amplification and selection of targets (CASTing) using a FLAG epitope-tagged truncated TAL1 gene product (AA 176 to 331) coexpressed in rabbit reticulocyte lysates with an 85-residue peptide containing the E47 bHLH domain. CASTing experiments were also performed using FLAG epitope-tagged TAL1 construct mixed with Jurkat cell nuclear extracts in order to identify a consensus TAL1 E-box sequence.Binding of the TAL1/E47 heterodimer and endogenous TAL1/E2A heterodimers to oligonucleotides containing the consensus TAL1 E-box sequence (CAGATG) was confirmed by gel shift. Participation of TAL1 in endogenous TAL1/E2A complexes obtained from Jurkat cell nucelar extracts was confirmed by antibody supershift.Cotransfection of TAL1 with E47 resulted in weak activation of a reporter construct containing six copies of the consensus TAL1 E-box (E1bCAT-E6) in C3H10T1/2 cells. In contrast, transfection of E47 without TAL1 strongly induced the reporter construct in the same cell line.	8016094	Transactivation	Human	Strong	Cotransfection of TAL1 with E47 resulted in weak activation of a reporter construct containing six copies of the consensus TAL1 E-box (E1bCAT-E6) in C3H10T1/2 cells.    21375		   T-box brain gene 1 Beta-Hairpin-Ribbon Group/Transcription Factor T-Domain  Gwenael Breard	    TF Gene	    Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	   All members of the T Box family so far examined bind to the DNA consensus sequence TCACACCT.To identify binding partners for the guanylate kinase domain of CASK (300172), Hsueh et al. (2000) carried out a yeast 2-hybrid screen of brain cDNA libraries, from which TBR1 was isolated. By deletion analysis, the C-terminal region of TBR1 (residues 342 to 681) was found to be necessary and sufficient for association with the guanylate kinase domain of CASK. When coexpressed in COS-7 cells, TBR1 and CASK were readily coprecipitated by antibodies directed against either individual protein. Hsueh et al. (2000) demonstrated that CASK enters the nucleus and binds to a specific DNA sequence (the T element) in a complex with TBR1. CASK acts as a coactivator of TBR1 to induce transcription of T element-containing genes, including reelin, a gene that is essential for cerebrocortical development.	10749215	DNA Binding	Human	Strong	To identify binding partners for the guanylate kinase domain of CASK (300172), Hsueh et al. (2000) carried out a yeast 2-hybrid screen of brain cDNA libraries, from which TBR1 was isolated. By deletion analysis, the C-terminal region of TBR1 (residues 342 to 681) was found to be necessary and sufficient for association with the guanylate kinase domain of CASK. When coexpressed in COS-7 cells, TBR1 and CASK were readily coprecipitated by antibodies directed against either individual protein. Hsueh et al. (2000) demonstrated that CASK enters the nucleus and binds to a specific DNA sequence (the T element) in a complex with TBR1. CASK acts as a coactivator of TBR1 to induce transcription of T element-containing genes, including reelin, a gene that is essential for cerebrocortical development.

   			   	       	      			  		      11239428	       Transactivation	    Mouse	    Medium	  The authors have clearly shown that Tbr1 is essential for several critical early events in cortical development, including proper lamination and formation of cortical input and output axonal projections.    21406  transcription factor 12  Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family		Gwenael Breard	TF Gene	      DNA-Binding: sequence-specific   Based on studies of the mouse and chicken cDNAs, Zhang and Bina (1992) proposed that transcripts of HTF4 can be differentially spliced to yield distinct but related proteins which are evolutionarily similar to the products of the E2A gene, also known as transcription factor-3 (TCF3). In vitro assays had shown that HTF4 can form heterodimers with other bHLH proteins of class A (e.g., the E2A proteins) and class B (e.g., the myogenic factors; MYF3, MYF5, and MYF6), as well as the inhibitor of DNA binding (ID1) and stem cell leukemia hematopoietic transcription factor (TAL1).	8163514	DNA Binding	Mouse	Strong	In DNA binding assays, (Doyle et al., 1994) found that complexes of HTF4 with the myogenic factors have a relatively high affinity for the E box motifs of the mE2 (CACGTG) and kappa E2/muE5 (CACCTG) types, whereas heterodimers of HTF4 and TAL1 interact poorly. They suggested that these results and those obtained from transient expression studies indicated that leukemogenesis caused by TAL1 might include a pathway where TAL1 would act as a negative regulator of gene expression by forming a complex with class A bHLH proteins

21413	    transcription factor 4	 Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family  Debra Fulton  TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	Tcf4 is a transcription factor. It binds DNA (by EMSA analysis) in a complex with TFIIB and transactivates an SSTRinr-reporter in human and mouse neuroblastoma cells. However, it does not transactive the reporter gene in HeLa and NIH 3T3 cells suggesting that additional factors may be needed for SEF-2 activation in the neuroblastoma cells.	8978694	DNA Binding; TF PPI; Transactivation	Human; Mouse	Strong	Various hSSTR2 promoter-reporter genes traniently transfected into SSTR2 expression human and mouse neuroblastoma cells lines demonstrate that transcriptional activity depends on the presence of an initiator element (E-box-inr). EMSA analysis demonstrates that Sef-2 forms a protein complex with TFIIB with Sef-2 bound to DNA.

	  		       	      	 		  15060161	TF PPI	    Human      Strong	Coimmunoprecipitation using anti-B-catenin Ab in HeLa cells cotransfected with B-catenin and Tcf4-HA followed by anti-HA Ab show that B-catenin and Tcf4 form a complex, while mutation of B-catenin at K345 abolishes the binding. Transfection study with luc reporter containing Tcf binding site shows less efficient activation when K345 is mutated. EMSA shows that acetylation of B-catenin increases Tcf4 binding in a dose-dependent manner, and immunoprecipitation followed by cotransfection of B-catenin and Tcf4 shows that in vivo, acetylated B-catenin is found to bind Tcf4 preferentially.

 		   	    	       				      	    15576399	   DNA Binding; TF PPI		  Mouse		 Strong	     ChIP and immunoprecipitation shows that Tcf4 binds to TBP element on Myc promoter and is associated with the adjacent SBE (SBE-A) element but not the distal SBE element. Smad1 is shown to bind to these SBE elements. EMSA with TBP shows retardation with nuclear extract and supershift with anti-Tcf4 Ab or anti-B-catenin Ab. Supershift occurs with anti-Smad1 AB as well, but only in kidney tissue. No retardation occurs when mutated TBP element is used for EMSA, and competition is observed with unlabeled probe.  EMSA with SBE-A shows supershifting with Smad1 and Tcf4 Abs, but only in kidney tissue. RNAi of Tcf4, which decreases cellular Tcf4 level by 85 %, results in similar decrease in Myc mRNA level.

protein X.  In vitro translated Mlx dimers bind to specific E-box-like sequences by EMSA (PMID: 10918583). 																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																		   21685	     thyrotroph embryonic factor	   Zipper-Type Group/Leucine Zipper Family     Gwenael Breard		   TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	A well studied TF that both binds to DNA and modulates expression.     8396764	 DNA Binding	Mouse Strong	  Authors isolated a murine cDNA clone (mTEF-1) from a cardiac cDNA library. The clone is highly homologous to Hela cell TEF-1. The in vitro transcription/translation product of mTEF-1 cDNA bound to the A element, and the DNA binding property of mTEF-1 was identical to that of the A2 factor. Transfection of mTEF-1 cDNA into muscle and non-muscle cells confirmed that mTEF-1 corresponds to A2, but not to A1 factors. The mTEF-1 mRNA is expressed abundantly in skeletal and cardiac muscles, kidney and lung, but it is also expressed at lower levels in other tissues. These results suggest that the M-CAT binding factors consist of two different factors; the ubiquitous A2 is encoded by mTEF-1, but the muscle-specific A1 factor is distinct from mTEF-1.

antibody directed against TBP, authors show that stimulation of transcription by the chimeric activators GAL-VP16, GAL-TEF-1 and GAL-ER(EF) requires the presence of factors which are tightly Gel-shift assays show that the native and recombinant protein can bind to the LSP sequence in mitochondrial DNA.  DNAse1 footprinting further defined this binding site.  In-vitro transcription experiments showed that TFAM can induce mitochondrial transcription.

transcription factor Dp 1			       Winged Helix-Turn-Helix/Transcription Factor Family	Gwenael Breard	   TF Gene	      DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	    The E2F transcription factor family regulates the expression of various cellular promoters, particularly those involved in the cell cycle. E2F factors bind to DNA as homodimers or heterodimers in association with dimerization partner DP1. TFDP1 may be the first example of a family of related transcription factors. The protein was isolated by virtue of its binding to a DNA sequence taken from the adenovirus E2A promoter. TFDP1 is a component of the DRTF1/E2F transcription factor complex, which coordinates events in the cell cycle by interacting with RB1, the retinoblastoma gene product, and RB-related proteinsTFDP1 has a predicted sequence of 410 amino acids with a region of similarity to E2F1, accounting for the ability of both to bind the same DNA sequence.	8446173	DNA Binding	Human	Strong	The protein was isolated by virtue of its binding to a DNA sequence taken from the adenovirus E2A promoter. TFDP1 is a component of the DRTF1/E2F transcription factor complex, which coordinates events in the cell cycle by interacting with RB1, the retinoblastoma gene product, and RB-related proteins.

Endogenously expressed {alpha}-globin protein is detected when both CP2b and CP2c are overexpressed in MEL cells by fluorescein isothiocyanate (green)-conjugated secondary antibody with anti-hemoglobin. The transcriptional activation domain resides in the N terminus of CP2b by yeast-one hybrid. EMAS assays demonstrate that CP2b binds DNA poorly.EMSAs in which CP2b is added with CP2a or CP2c in the reaction mixture at different times demonstrates that erythroid cell-specific transcriptional activation of CP2b is mediated by the interaction with another CP2 isoform(s) that occupy the CP2c binding site in the {alpha}-globin promoter.Yeast-two hybrid analysis and ChIp assays (in MEL cells) indicate that PIAS1 is a component in the CP2b/CP2c complex in CP2b mediated {alpha}-globin gene expression. EMSAs, supershift and  {alpha}-globin promoter-reporter assays in confirm the complex CP2b/CP2c/PIAS1 and its ability to transactivate the reporter gene.

  23857		cyclin D binding myb-like transcription factor 1	Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Myb Domain Family  Gwenael Breard		       TF Gene		 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	  DMP1 contains three tandem Myb-like repeats in its central portion that are flanked by acidic transactivating domains at both termini. The Myb-like motifs are required for DNA binding, but unlike other Myb family members, DMP1 binds to nonameric consensus sequences containing core GGA/T residues, a subset of which are also bound by Ets family proteins. This ability of DMP1 to inhibit cell proliferation depends upon its DNA binding and transactivation functions, because mutants disrupted in either of these domains are biologically inert.Inoue et al. demonstrated that DMP1 is responsible of the regulation of CD13 (encoding aminopeptidase N).	8425553	DNA Binding	Mouse	Not Selected	The Ets family of transcription factors.

 23942	     metastasis-associated gene family, member 2    	      Gwenael Breard	       TF Gene	 Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding	MTA2 modulates the enzymatic activity of the histone deacetylase core complex.In 1998, several different groups simultaneously described the protein composition of a macromolecular histone deacetylase complex variously termed the Mi-2 complex, NuRD, NURDor NRD.The Mi-2/NuRD complex unexpectedly provided a physical link between histone deacetylation and ATP-dependent chromatin remodeling.Four different groups reported on the identity of a major Mi-2/NuRD polypeptide of approximately 70–80 kDa. In the human complex designated as NuRD, this protein was reported as the product of the MTA2 gene. In contrast, MTA1 was identified as a component of a strikingly similar human complex termed NURD. In the Mi-2 complex isolated from the amphibian X. laevis, the subunit of similar size was identified as MTA1-like, a gene product now recognized to be the ortholog of mammalian MTA2. Finally, the HDAC1 cII complex was reported to contain MTA2 as well as two ‘truncated forms’ of MTA2.	11749719	Transactivation	Mouse	Weak	The entire mmta2 protein repressed the transcription of the reporter genes, whereas treatment with a histone deacetylase inhibitor, trichostatin A (TSA), led to recovery from the repression and to transcriptional activation. However, the N terminus of mmta2 activated transcriptional activity in the absence of TSA. These results suggest that mmta2 has the potential to both repress and activate gene transcription and that its transcription repression activity might be related to histone deacetylation.

     		       						     	    	      10406464		    Co-activation; TF PPI	 Mouse	    Strong   TRAP100, a component of TR/TRAP complex,  contains 7 LxxLL motifs that are known for NR interactions, but GST-TRAP100 fusion protein used in GST pull-down assay did not bind various NRs, suggesting that TRAP100 does not bind to NRs directly.      24068	  steroid receptor RNA activator 1	       Magdalena Swanson    TF Gene   Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	Sra1 is a TF gene.  In transient transfection studies, recombinant SRA enhanced progestin receptor transactivation in a CAT reporter assay and was shown to function as a thyroid hormone-dependent coactivator for thyroid hormone receptors TRalpha1 and TRbeta1 in a luciferase reporter assay.  In coimmunoprecipitation studies done on mammalian cell extracts, SRA RNA was found to be complexed to Steroid receptor coactivator 1 (SRC-1) and to coprecipitate with murine thyroid hormone receptors TRalpha1 and TRbeta1.  Therefore it appears to carry out its coactivator function in the form of an RNA molecule.	10199399	Co-activation; Other	Human	Strong	Experiments in HeLa cells cotransfected with recombinant human progestin receptor and recombinant human SRA along with a (PRE)2-TATA-CAT reporter plasmid containing the progestin receptor elements showed that SRA enhanced progestin receptor transactivation. SRA RNA was found to be complexed to Steroid receptor coactivator 1 (SRC-1) in coimmunoprecipitation studies in HeLa cells.  HeLa cell lysates were fractionated and subjected to immunoprecipitation with antibodies against SRC-1 and analyzed by RT-PCR.

   26427     cAMP responsive element binding protein 3-like 1 Zipper-Type Group/Leucine Zipper Family	Gwenael Breard	TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	OASIS is a basic leucine zipper (bZIP) transcription factor of the CREB/ATF family with a transmembrane domain that allows it to associate with the ER. The molecule is cleaved at the membrane in response to ER stress, and its cleaved amino-terminal cytoplasmic domain, which contains the bZIP domain, translocates into the nucleus where it activates the transcription of target genes that are mediated by ER stress-responsive and cyclic AMP-responsive elements.	15665855	DNA Binding	Human	Strong	OASIS, a CREB/ATF-family member, modulates UPR signalling in astrocytes.

    26910	   folliculogenesis specific basic helix-loop-helix    Zipper-Type Group/Helix-Loop-Helix Family	Tim Hughes	TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	This gene is also known as FIGalpha.  It is an HLH protein identified in a search for factors that associate physically with the E12 isoform of E2A (PMID: 9362457).  The FIGalpha transcript is specific to ovaries (and to some degree testis) and antibodies against FIGalpha supershift a protein complex from ovaries that binds the  E-box (CANNTG) located approximately 200 bp upstream of the transcription start sites of Zona Pellucida glycoprotein genes Zp1, Zp2 and Zp3 (PMID: 9362457).  Full activation of a reporter construct containing 1.5 kb of the Zp2 promoter is dependent on the E-box as well as cotransfection of both E12 and Figalpha, in a transient cotransfection assay (PMID: 9362457).  FIGalpha null mice do not express Zp1, Zp2, or Zp3 (PMID: 11023867).  In vitro transcribed and translated Figla protein binds E-box sequences by EMSA (PMID: 15044608) and forms an apparent ternary complex when E12 protein is added.  Competition by cold competitor is dependent upon the E-box, demonstrating specificity (PMID: 15044608).	9362457	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Mouse	Not Selected	It is an HLH protein identified in a search for factors that associate physically with the E12 isoform of E2A.  26992		bromodomain containing 7			 	Jared Roach	 TF Gene       Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding	This is on the line between "candidate" and certainty, but based on the abstract of PMID 12489984, I will classify it as a TF that functions through heterochromatin interaction.    12489984 Co-activation	       Unknown	Strong	   "Using yeast two-hybrid screening, we identified a novel chromatin-associated bromodomain-containing protein, BRD7, as an E1B-AP5 interaction partner. We confirmed E1B-AP5-BRD7 complex formation in vivo and in vitro. We found that, although BRD7 binds to histones H2A, H2B, H3 and H4 through its bromodomain, this domain was not necessary for the interaction with E1B-AP5. Indeed, the triple complex formation of E1B-AP5, BRD7 and histones was demonstrated. Disruption of the E1B-AP5-BRD7 complex increased E1B-AP5 repression activity for basic transcription and converted it from being an activator of the hormone-dependent promoter into being a strong repressor. We conclude that complex formation between BRD7 and E1B-AP5 links chromatin events with mRNA processing at the level of transcriptional regulation."

binding    Olig2 is a transcription factor. It interacts with p300 (by coimmunoprecipitation) both invitro and invivo (in neuroepithelial cells) and inhibits the binding of Stat2 with p300. Cotransfection of neuroepithelial cells with a GFAP promoter-luciferase reporter vector together with or without an OLIG2 expression vector demonstrates that OLIG2 represses GFAP gene transcription. Similarly, enforced expression of OLIG2 inhibits astrocytic differentiation in neuroepithelial cells (by immunocytochemistry). Olig2 binds E-boxes motifs in the Hb9 promoter by mobility shift, binding competition, and ChIP assays. Olig2 interacts with itself, E47, and Ngn2 by yeast two-hybrid and immunoprecipitation assays.	    14576772	  TF PPI   Mouse	  Strong	Cotransfection of neuroepithelial cells with a GFAP promoter-luciferase reporter vector together with or without an OLIG2 expression vector (stimulated with LIF - known to induce astrocytic differentiation) demonstrates that OLIG2 represses GFAP gene transcription. OLIG2 is coimmunoprecipitated with p300 in COS-7 cells demonstrating that OLIG2 binds to p300. Endogenous p300 protein associates with endogenous OLIG2 protein in the neuroepithelial cells indicating that this interaction occurs invivo (by immunoprecipitation). Cotransfection of p300 and STAT3 in the absence or presence of OLIG2 in COS-7 cells demonstrates that p300 and STAT3 interact (by coimmunoprecipitated with p300) and in the presence of OLIG2 the interaction between STAT3 and p300 was inhibited. p300 deletion mutants and full-length OLIG2 expressed in COS-7 cells, we concluded that both the N- and C-termini of p300 can interact with OLIG2 by immunoprecipitation. Cotransfection of a recombinant OLIG2 retrovirus that encodes both OLIG2 and green fluorescent protein (GFP) genes in neuroepithelial cells (by immunocytochemistry) demonstrates that enforced expression of OLIG2 inhibits astrocytic differentiation.

binding  Olig1 is a transcription factor. Olig1 binds a bHLH binding site in a sequence specific manner (and Sox10 binds sox binding sites) by electrophoretic mobility shift, mutated radiolabeled probes, and supershift assays. proteins of the mammalian Polycomb complex (Ring1A, Ring1B, and M33) by 2-hybrid, co-immunoprecipitation, and/or GST pulldown (PMID: 10369680).  It also iteracts physically with YY1 by GST pulldown.  By reporter co-transfection assay with a GAL4 fusion protein, RYBP acted as a repressor.RYBP was also been identified as a protein that interacts with E2F2 and E2F3 by 2-hybrid analysis (PMID: 12411495). By Chip assay, YY1, E2F and RYB all interact with the Cdc6 and RR1 promoters.This protein contains a ZnF_RBZ domain, of which the defining member is Ran, which is a protein that regulates transport between the nucleus and the cytoplasm. different nuclear receptor signalling (at least ER and AR), as it was shown to be essential for coactivation by p160 HAT family members of the nuclear response elements.There is support for a role for    57765     T-box 21	     Beta-Hairpin-Ribbon Group/Transcription Factor T-Domain   Tim Hughes	 TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific     This gene encodes an apparent member of the T-box family of transcription factors involved in the immune response.  It was identified by a yeast one hybrid approach using the IL-2 promoter (-400 to &#8722;40) linked to the HIS3 reporter gene (PMID: 10761931).  In a cotransfection assay, it could transactivate a reporter construct containing the entire IFN&#947; locus, which includes three potential T-box consensus binding sequences, but it repressed the IL-2 promoter (PMID: 10761931).  T-bet protein can be “immunoprecipitated” by biotinylated oligonucleotides containing wild-type but not mutated T-box binding sites (PMID: 16275766).  By co-immunoprecipitation, T-bet associates with NF-kappaB RelA (PMID: 16275766) and also with GATA-3, and it also interferes with GATA-3 DNA-binding in a gel-shift assay (PMID: 15662016).	10761931	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Human; Mouse	Not Selected	Identified by a yeast one hybrid approach using the IL-2 promoter (-400 to ?40) linked to the HIS3 reporter gene. binding		 The TATA-binding protein (TBP)-associated factors (TAFs) of TFIID play a central role in RNA polymerase II transcriptional regulation.   72504	  TAF4B RNA polymerase II, TATA box binding protein (TBP)-associated factor   		 Magdalena Swanson     TF Gene	  Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding  Taf4b is a TF gene.  Taf4b from murine ovarian extracts interacts with the cell type-specific subunit of TFIID, called TAFII105, and TATA-binding protein (TBP) in immunoprecipitation studies. Luciferase reporter assays in spontaneously immortalized granulosa cells (SIGCs) and NIH/3T3 cells stably overexpressing Taf4b show that Taf4b transactivates granulosa cell-specific promoters on transiently transfected reporter constructs, such as the inhibin-&#945; (Inha) and -&#946;A (Inhba) subunit promoters, and the cyclin D2 (Ccnd2) and follistatin (Fst) promoters.	11557891	TF PPI	Mouse	Strong	Immunoprecipitation (IP) of murine ovarian extracts with anti-TBP antibody showed that murine TAFII105 specifically coprecipitates with the cell type-specific subunit of TFIID, called TAFII105, and TATA-binding protein (TBP), as detected by anti-TAFII250, anti-TAFII105, and anti-TBP antibodies.

   72949	    cyclin T2	     	    Elodie Portales-Casamar	      TF Gene		 Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding  ccnt2 is one possible regulatory subunit of the complexe P-TEFb. P-TEFb contains Cdk9 and a C-type cyclin (CycT1, CycT2a, CycT2b or CycK). Cdk9 in P-TEFb phosphorylates the C-terminal domain (CTD) of RNAPII.Ccnt2 has been shown to bind directly to RNAPII and this interaction is key for its transcriptional effects.It is also part of a complexe with MyoD, involved in MyoD transcriptional activation.It was shown that Ccnt2 can activate transcription when tethered artificially to DNA.It is possible though that the involvment of ccnt2 is only through the kinase activity of cdk9 which would give it more a role in signalling than in transcription itself.	12037670	Co-activation	Mouse	Medium	Ccnt2 associated with cdk9 enhances the transcriptional activity of MyoD (gene reporter assay with the MyoD-dependent promoter 4RE-luc in NIH3T3 cells).The kinase activity of cdk9 is necessary during muscle differentiation (C2C12 stable cell lines with different cdk9 mutants and gene reporter assay with the MCK-luc reporter in those cell lines).The N-terminus of cdk9 directly interacts in vitro with the bHLH domain of MyoD (GST-MyoD pull down with an in vitro translated cdk9).Cdk9, MyoD and cycT2 form a multimeric complex in vivo (co-IP in C2C12 cells in growth or differentiation medium).Cdk9 phosphorylates MyoD in vitro and its kinase activity peaks in the early phase of the differentiation program (in vitro kinase assay).

	       	       	      Magdalena Swanson	    TF Gene	 DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	     Nfatc4 is a transcription factor.  It activates transcription of an NFAT luciferase reporter plasmid in transient cotransfection experiments.  It also binds to promoter elements in the IL-2, PPAR&#947;2 and adiponectin promoters in electrophoretic mobility shift assays, and does not bind to mutated or non-specific oligonucleotides.	       11997522		    DNA Binding; Transactivation      Human	    Strong Transfection assays with an NFAT luciferase reporter plasmid together with an expression vector for wild-type NFATc4 in BHK cells show that Nfatc4 activates transcription. NFATc4 binds to the IL-2 promoter, and to two distinct sites on the PPAR&#947;2 promoter in electrophoretic mobility shift assays. Flag epitope-tagged NFATc4 proteins were expressed in COS cells and nuclear extracts were prepared for gel mobility shift assays. Probes consisted of oligonucleotides encoding the canonical NFAT binding site from the IL-2 gene promoter (IL-2), and proximal and distal NFAT elements of the PPAR&#947;2 gene promoter.

 	       			  	  Stuart Lithwick	  TF Gene      DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	GeneID: 73181Referring to PMID: 16644691NFATc4 is a transcription factor. When cotransfected with adiponectin reporter constructs, NFATc4 stimulated 50% increases in reporter activity. Futhermore, these increases in reporter expression were observed only in the presence of the putative NFAT-binding site. Using EMSA assays, NFATc4 was also shown to interact with a 20 bp region within the adiponectin promoter from mouse 3T3-L1 adipocytes, mouse white adipose tissue, and human HEK293 kidney cells. In addition, ChIP assays were also performed, lending in-vivo confidence to this claim.	16644691	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Human; Mouse	Strong	GeneID: 73181Referring to PMID: 16644691Function: Transactivation (strong)NFATc4 represses adiponectin promoter activity dependent on the putative NFAT binding site. Cotransfection of NFATc4 (species not specified) expression vector and mouse adiponectin-luciferase reporter constructs into fully differentiated mouse 3T3-L1 adipocytes led to significant reductions in promoter activity (50%) relative to controls. Appropriate controls were also included; NFATc1, c2, and c3 all failed to reduce promoter activity. So NFATc4 is likely responsible for repression of adiponectin expression in the natural promoter context. Function: Transactivation based upon a specific DNA region (strong)Repression of adiponectin promoter activity by NFATc4 is dependent upon the repressor region containing the putative NFATC4 binding site. Additional cotransfection assays were performed with mouse adiponectin promoter constructs in which the putative NFAT binding site is included or excluded. The promoter activities of reporters including the binding site were reduced by NFATc4, while those with the binding site excluded were unaffected. Taken together, these results demonstrate that NFATc4 represses the promoter activity of adiponectin genes, dependent upon the putative NFAT binding site (�363 to �344) of the mouse adiponectin promoter.Function: DNA-binding (strong)NFATc4 was shown to interact directly with a 20-bp region of the adiponectin promoter containing the putative NFAT-binding site. EMSAs using nuclear extracts from fully differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes, mouse white adipose tissue, and human HEK293 kidney cells were performed. For this experiment, a 20-bp wild-type oligonucleotide (�363 to �344) was designed that cover the putative NFAT binding site containing the core sequence of the NFAT response element (GGAAA) (Fig. 3A). Using nuclear extracts from both 3T3-L1 cells (Fig. 3B, left panel) and mouse white adipose tissue (Fig. 3B, middle panel), binding complexes were observed with the labeled 20-bp oligonucleotides. Competitive inhibitors were also able to eliminate the mobility shift. To identify the protein binding to the putative NFAT site as NFATc4, a supershift assay was conducted using anti-NFATc4. Anti-NFATc4 shifted the binding complex. In contrast, no supershifted complex was detected with anti-STAT-1 (Fig. 3B). The evidence from this EMSA is strong due to the comprehensive set of controls that were included.

74164	     nuclear transcription factor, X-box binding 1	  	 Sarav Sundararajan	       TF Gene		     Single stranded RNA/DNA binding			       7964459	DNA Binding; Transactivation	    Human Strong	     This paper describes the cloning of the human NFX1 gene.  EMSA studies show that NFX1 binds to a DRA X1 box which is competed for by oligonucleotides containing the analogous regions from the HLA-DRB, -DPA, -DPB, -DQA, and -DQB promoters.  CAT reporter assays show that NFX1 encodes a transcription factor capable of transrepression of HLA-DRA gene expression.

75605	     jumonji, AT rich interactive domain 1B (Rbp2 like)		       Debra Fulton	       TF Gene		     Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	       Jarid1b is a transcription factor. Jarid1v interacts with BF-1 and PAX9 by yeast two-hybrid assay and immunoprecipitation assays. A Gal4-Jarid1v fusion protein reduces the basal expression of the reporter gene and co-expression of BF-1 further represses reporter gene activation through a motif required for interaction (by reporter gene assay with deletion/mutation analysis).       12657635		  TF PPI; Transactivation	Mouse	Strong	PLU-1 interacts with BF-1 and PAX9 by yeast two-hybrid assay (screening of a human fetal brain library) and interaction is mediated through a conserved motif: (Ala-X-Ala-Ala-X-Val-Pro-X4-Val-Pro-X8-Pro) by deletion constructs in a yeast two-hybrid interaction assay.  PLU-1 and endogenous PAX9 can interact in vivo by immunopreciptation assays in human mammary epithelial cell line 1�7HB2 and PLU-1 and BF-1 can interact in vivo by immunopreciptation assays in HT1080 cell. GAL4DBD-PLU-1 fusion constructs in HEK293 cells demonstrates that PLU-1 dramatically reduces the basal expression of the reporter gene and co-transfection of BF-1 shows a greater repression. This interaction is mediated through the conserved motif (noted above) by co-immunoprecipitation assays in HEK293 cells.

94246	AT rich interactive domain 4B (Rbp1 like)	   		Stuart Lithwick	       TF Gene	      Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding   Human Arid4b (referred to as SAP180 in this PMID) is likely a transcriptional cofactor, which represses gene expression in a complex with a variety of other co-repressor proteins. Arid4b represses luciferase reporter expression when fused to the GAL4-DBD and cotransfected into HEK-293 cells along with a luciferase reporter vector. In addition, Arid4b interacts with each of the components of the mSIN3A corepressor complex as demonstrated by co-immunoprecipitation from K562 nuclear extracts. This suggests that transcriptional repression by Arid4b is achieved via the action of Histone Deacetylase (HDAC). However, the addition of HDAC inhibitor TSA to the cotransfection experiment did not impact upon the ability of Arid4b to repress expression suggesting that it may be by other means.	12724404	Co-activation; TF PPI	Human; Unknown	Medium	Arid4b (referred to by its alias, SAP180, in this PMID) repressed reporter transcription in a cotransfection assay in which an expression vector for Arid4b fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain was transfected into HEK-293 cells along with a luciferase reporter vector. Addition of Histone Deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor TSA had little to no effect on the transcriptional reporession by GAL-Arid4b. Human Arid4b co-immunoprecipitated with human mSin3A, HDAC1, HDAC2, and mSDS3, all components of the mSin3A co-repressor complex in a co-immunoprecipitation assay in which each of the co-repressor complex components was immunoprecipitated from K562 nuclear extracts, and Arid4b was detected through Western blotting using anti-Arid4b.

two-hybrid experiment designed to identify proteins that interacted with the thyroid hormone receptor carboxy terminus.HMGN3, expressed in bacteria as an His epitope tagged protein, binds to nucleosome core particles in gel shift assays. Random amplified polymorphic DNA (RAPD) analysis demonstrates that this binding displays no sequence specificity. Microarray analysis was used to identifiy prospective HMGN3 target genes in transiently transfected mouse Hepa-1 hepatoma cells. The differentially regulated targets included the glycine transporter 1 gene (Glyt1). HMGN3 induction of Glyt1 was confirmed by RT-PCR using RNA obtained from transiently transfected Hepa-1 cells. The differentially regulated targets included the glycine transporter 1 gene (Glyt1). HMGN3 induction of Glyt1 was confirmed by RT-PCR using RNA obtained from transiently transfected Hepa-1 cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies demonstrated that HMGN3 interacted with the Glyt1 gene promoter in the same cell line.

   99377     sal-like 4 (Drosophila)	  Zinc-coordinating Group/BetaBetaAlpha-zinc finger Family	    Stuart Lithwick  TF Gene		      DNA-Binding: non-sequence-specific; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding; Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding	      Sall4 is a transcription factor implicated in the mouse limb and heart patterning, which binds to DNA sequences either alone or in complex with other transcription factors, and thereby regulates transcription. Sall4 influences levels of reporter gene expression when cotransfected into 10T1/2 cells along with reporter constructs containing either mouse Fgf10, Gja15 or Nppa promoter sequences. This regulation is modified upon the further transfection of Tbx family members. Sall4 binds directly to transcription factor Nanog, as demonstrated by reciprocal Chromatin Immunoprecipitations from mouse embryonic stem cells.	16380715	Co-activation	Human; Mouse	Strong	Sall4 activated luciferase reporter expression in a co-transfection assay in which an expression vector encoding mouse Sall4 was transfected into 10T1/2 cells along with a reporter plasmid consisting of the Fgf10 promoter fused to luciferase. Luciferase expression increased synergistically upon the additional transfection of an expression plasmid encoding either Tbx4 or Tbx5. This synergism was eliminated upon the usage of a reporter vector with a mutation within the Tbx5 binding site (T-Box element). Cotransfection of expression vectors for Tbx2 or Tbx3 along with that for Sall4, Tbx5, and a reporter vector, prevented the activation of luciferase gene expression.  Sall4 activated Gja5 promoter expression and suppressed Nppa promoter expression in co-transfection assays, in which an expression vector for Sall4 was transfected into 10T1/2 cells along with a reporter plasmid consisting of either the Gja5 promoter or Nppa promoter fused to luciferase. Sall4 counteracted Nppa promoter activation by Tbx5 but not that by Nkx2-5 or Gata-4 when co-transfected with expression vectors for each protein into 10T1/2 cells.

   		     		 			   	  		      16079794		    Other  Human    Medium	 The BHC complex is composed of six subunits, including the histone deacetylase HDAC1/2, the SANT-domain-containing protein CoREST, the PHD-domain-containing protein BHC80, the HMG-domain-containing protein BRAF35, and the recently described histone demethylase BHC110 (also known as LSD1).To define the subunit(s) involved in modulating the activity of BHC110 for H3K4 demethylation, they reconstituted the previously defined BHC complex using recombinant subunits produced in insect cells. Addition of CoREST not only enhanced H3K4 demethylation, but also yielded increased H3 deacetylation activity on core histone substrates.CoREST enhances the association between BHC110 and nucleosomes.

     106298		RRN3 RNA polymerase I transcription factor homolog (yeast) 	  Jared Roach	TF Gene	  Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	 #JR#2-7-06OMIM:"Eukaryotic ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes are transcribed by an enzyme solely dedicated to that purpose, RNA polymerase I (Pol I; see 602000), and their expression is coordinated with cellular growth rate. Using the protein sequence of the yeast Pol I transcription factor Rrn3, Moorefield et al. (2000) identified EST sequences which they used to isolate a partial RRN3 cDNA clone from human Jurkat cell RNA. By 5-prime and 3-prime RACE, they cloned several cDNA fragments which were joined at overlapping restriction enzyme sites to produce an ORF encoding a 587-amino acid protein that shares 21% sequence similarity as well as immunologic cross-reactivity with the yeast Rrn3 transcription factor."Rrn3 is an rRNA TF. NCBI "Conserved Domain" search idenitifies only pfam05327.5 (RRN3: RNA polymerase I specific transcription initiation factor RRN3. This family consists of several eukaryotic proteins which are homologous to the yeast RRN3 protein. RRN3 is one of the RRN genes specifically required for the transcription of rDNA by RNA polymerase I (Pol I) in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.). There is no direct experimental evidence of DNA binding in mammmals, so this gene is therefore could conceivable be considered for the ontology notation "DNA-binding: sequence-specific".	8670901	Co-activation	Other	Strong	The authors state: "Rrn3p appears to interact directly with Pol I, apparently stimulating Pol I recruitment to the promoter, and is distinct from two other Pol I-specific transcription factors, the Rrn6/7 complex and the Rrn5/9/10 complex (UAF), characterized previously." This suggests that Rrn3 may not directly bind DNA.
