107182		   BTAF1 RNA polymerase II, B-TFIID transcription factor-associated, (Mot1 homolog, S. cerevisiae)   	      Amy Ticoll	      TF Gene	  Basal Transcription Factor	    Together Btaf1 and the TATA-binding protein (TBP) are the major components of TFIID (see PMID:14557059 for Review). The amino terminus of hTAFII170 is found to interact with hTBP through deletion mutation analysis in a yeast two-hybrid system. Results are confirmed with GST pull-down and coimmunoprecipitation assays.	11585931	TF PPI	Human	Strong	TBP-binding regions in human TAFII170 (BTAF1) are identified. The amino terminus of hTAFII170 is found to interact with hTBP through deletion mutation analysis in a yeast two-hybrid system. Results are confirmed in a similar studies with Flag-tagged hTAFII170 and GST-hTBP, as well as coimmunoprecipitation of the endogenous proteins in COS-7 cells. These and further experiments support a mechanism in which TAFII170 induces high-mobility DNA binding by TBP through reversible interactions with its concave DNA binding surface.

  108098      mediator complex subunit 21 	  Elodie Portales-Casamar  TF Gene	Basal Transcription Factor	Surb7 is part of the RNA polymerase II holoenzyme. The basal transcription factors TFIIE and TFIIH were also shown to be in the complex.The available data indicate that the yeast holoenzyme is responsible for all mRNA transcription initiation in a cell. The mammalian counterpart of the yeast holoenzyme has been less studied.	8598913	Co-activation	Human	Strong	Surb7 is part of the RNA polymerase II holoenzyme (CTD-affinity chromatography from HeLa cells with use of specific antibodies). This RNA polymerase II holoenzyme also contains the general transcription factors TFIIE and TFIIH.This holoenzyme is more responsive to transcriptional activators than core RNA polymerase II when assayed in the presence of coactivators.

  	       					  	 		   9159119	Co-activation	    Human	Strong	 Intact BRCA1 is a component of the RNA pol II holoenzyme in HeLa cell extracts. This has been shown by (i) copurification of a significant fraction (50%) of the BRCA1 in the cell with a complex containing pol II and the SRB10 homologue Cdk8; (ii) by coimmunopurification of BRCA1, Surb7, pol II, TFIIF, TFIIE, and TFIIH; and (iii) by association of epitope-tagged wild-type BRCA1 with the Surb7-containing complex in cells.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																						   108143	TAF9 RNA polymerase II, TATA box binding protein (TBP)-associated factor    	Gwenael Breard	  TF Gene Basal Transcription Factor   RNA polymerase II transcription factor IID is a complex of the TATA binding protein and a variety of TBP-associated factors (TAFs). The TAFs are required for activated rather than basal transcription and serve to mediate signals between various activators and the basal transcriptional machinery. Taf9 is one of these TBP-associated factors.Klemm et al. (1995) cloned a human TFIID subunit, which they termed hTAFII32. The 32-kD protein was isolated from HeLa cell nuclear extracts and partially sequenced. A degenerate oligomer was designed and used to probe a human HeLa cell cDNA library. The identified cDNA has a deduced amino acid sequence of 264 residues and is related to the Drosophila TAFII40. Klemm et al. (1995) showed that TAFII32 interacts with GTF2B and with the viral transcriptional transactivator VP16. The authors showed that recombinantly expressed TAFII32 was functional in a partial recombinant TFIID complex and that the recombinant complex mediated activation by a GAL4-VP16 fusion protein. Lu and Levine (1995) cloned TAF9, which they called TAFII31. TAF9 encodes a 264-amino acid protein. Immunoprecipitation and binding analyses showed interaction of TAF9 with the N-terminal domain of p53 at sites identical to those bound by MDM2, the major cellular negative regulator of p53 activity. Antibodies to TAF9 inhibited p53-activated transcription. Lu and Levine (1995) concluded that p53 activity is regulated by 2 proteins competing for the same region of the p53 protein.	7597030	TF PPI	Human	Strong	Transcription factor TFIID consists of TATA binding protein (TBP) and at least eight TBP-associated factors (TAFs). As TAFs are required for activated but not basal transcription, we have proposed that TAFs act as coactivators to mediate signals between activators and the basal transcription machinery. Here we report the cloning, expression, and biochemical characterization of the 32-kDa subunit of human (h) TFIID, termed hTAFII32. We find that hTAFII32 is the human homologue of Drosophila TAFII40. In vitro protein-protein interaction assays reveal that as observed with Drosophila TAFII40, hTAFII32 interacts with the C-terminal 39-amino acid activation domain of the acidic transactivator viral protein 16 (VP16) as well as with the general transcription factor TFIIB. Moreover, a partial recombinant TFIID complex containing hTAFII32 was capable of mediating in vitro transcriptional activation by the VP16 activation domain. These findings indicate that specific activator-coactivator interactions have been conserved between human and Drosophila and provide additional support for the function of these interactions in mediating transcriptional activation.
																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																						   		     	 	    	     	 7761466 Co-activation		  Human		Strong	The p53 protein activates transcription of a target gene by binding to a specific DNA response element and interacting with the transcriptional apparatus of RNA polymerase II. The amino-terminal domain of p53 interacts with a component of the TFIID basal transcription complex. The human TATA-binding-protein-associated factor TAFII31, a component of TFIID, has been identified as a critical protein required for p53-mediated transcriptional activation. TAFII31 and p53 proteins bind to each other via amino acid residues in the amino-terminal domain of p53 that are essential for transcription. Antibodies directed against TAFII31 protein inhibit p53-activated but not basal transcription in vitro. These results demonstrate that TAFII31 is a coactivator for the p53 protein.

108655	 forkhead box P1	  Winged Helix-Turn-Helix/Forkhead Domain Family  Jared Roach	TF Gene	    DNA-Binding: sequence-specific    From OMIM: "Li and Tucker (1993) cloned a glutamine-rich factor,   2247086	 DNA Binding; Transactivation	 Mouse	Medium	      Various regions of the mouse alphaA-crystallin promoter containing the alphaA-CRYBP1 site were cloned into the pTKCAT plasmid. The plasmids were cotranfected with pTB1 into alphaTN4-1 (mouse lens epithelial), L929 (mouse fibroblast), PLE (embryonic chicken lens epithelial), and CEF (embryonic chicken fibroblast) cell lines. The mouse alphaA-crystallin -73/-55 region stimulated the tk promoter in alphaTN2-1 cells but not in any of the other cell lines. The alphaA-CRYBP1 site (GGGAAATCCC) alone augmented the activity of the tk promoter 3-4x in alphaTN2-1 cells but not in any of the other cell lines. Mutation of the site eliminated transcriptional activity of the alphaA-crystallin promoter.Oligos containing two, three, or four copies of mouse alphaA-CRYBP1 site were cloned into pTKCAT upstream of the tk promoter and used for transfection. CAT activity increased with copy number in all transfected cell types. Preliminary gel mobility shift assays indicate that both alphaTN4-1 and L929 nuclear extracts produced multiple DNA-protein complexes with the mouse alphaA-CRYBP1 site, despite the lack of transactivation in L929.

    114606	 transducin-like enhancer of split 6, homolog of Drosophila E(spl)	    Stuart Lithwick  TF Gene   Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	     Tle6 is a transcription factor, which regulates gene expression in complex with other transcription factors. Tle6 associates with transcription factor BF-1 as demonstrated by co-immunoprecipitation, and modulates the transcriptional repression activity of BF-1 as demonstrated by cotransfection. As well, Tle6 cannot inherently repress transcription, and does not inherently modulate the ability of Tle1 to repress transcription as demonstrated by cotransfection. Instead it is thought that it may compete with Tle1 for binding to BF-1 and thereby bring about decreased gene expression.	16314515	TF PPI	Mouse	Strong	Tle6 (referred to by its alias Grg6 in this PMID) co-immunoprecipitated with BF-1 in a co-immunoprecipitation assay in which FLAG-BF1 was immunoprecipitated from nuclear extracts of HEK293 cells co-transfected with FLAG-BF1 and GFP-Tle6 using anti-FLAG, and GFP-Tle6 was detected by Western blotting using anti-GFP.Tle6 modulated the transcriptional repression activity of BF-1, producing an increase in reporter expression relative to just BF-1 and reporter, in a cotransfection assay in which HEK293 cells were cotransfected with expression vectors for Tle6 and BF-1, as well as a reporter construct vector consisting of six tandem copies of a BF-1 binding site fused to luciferase. This modulative effect of Tle6 was antagonized by the further transfection of Tle1. Tle6 had no effect on reporter gene expression when cotransfected with a mutant form of BF-1 unable to bind DNA and thereby mediate reporter repression. Tle1 fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain repressed reporter expression in a cotransfection assay in which HeLa cells were cotransfected with an expression vector for Tle1-GAL4DBD along with a reporter construct vector consisting of five tandem copies of a GAL4 binding site fused to luciferase. No reporter gene repression was observed upon cotransfection of Tle6-GALDBD expression plasmid and reporter plasmid into HeLa cells. Tle6 did not impede the ability of BF-1-binding protein Tle1 fused to the GAL4 DNA-binding domain to repress reporter expression when cotransfected into HeLa cells with an expression vector for Tle-1 along with a reporter construct consisting of five tandem repeats of the GAL4 upstream activation sequence and the SV40 promoter fused to luciferase.

    114741	 suppressor of Ty 16 homolog (S. cerevisiae)  	 Tim Hughes TF Gene	    Basal Transcription Factor This gene encodes a protein that is a component of a complex required for RNA polymerase II to transcribe through chromatin (PMID: 10421373).  It destabilizes nucleosomal structure so that one histone H2A-H2B dimer is removed during enzyme passage (PMID: 12934006).  I did not read all 15 papers about this gene and it is not clear to me which of this information comes from yeast and how much comes from mouse/human; however, it is evident that the encoded protein does at least have similar activities in both yeast and human on the basis of biochemical studies.  Therefore I think it can be considered a "TF gene" and I am classifying it as a "Basal Transcription Factor" although it could also be deemed as interacting with chromatin (but probably not heterochromatin). 10421373		      Other Human    Not Selected Gene encodes a protein that is a component of a complex required for RNA polymerase II to transcribe through chromatin.

     208677	    cAMP responsive element binding protein 3-like 3   Zipper-Type Group/Leucine Zipper Family		 Shannan HoSui TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: sequence-specific CREB-H is a liver-enriched transcription factor that binds specifically to CRE and box-B elements.  DNA binding has been demonstrated using gel mobility shift assays.  CREB-H acts as a transactivator, as shown by lucerifase assay. Deletion of the putative transmembrane domain increased activation, suggesting that the transmembrane domain may be involved in modulating activity.	11353085	DNA Binding; Transactivation	Human	Strong	In the initial screening experiment with RT�PCR, the authors observed the liver-specific expression of CREB-H using 16 human tissues. To confirm this observation, they performed northern blotting analysis with the 16 human tissues.  To determine whether CREB-H is a transcription activator, plasmids expressing GAL4�CREB-H fusion proteins were produced and co-transfected with a luciferase-reporter plasmid containing the GAL4 DNA-binding element into COS7 cells.  CREB-H functioned as a transcriptional activator and its N-terminal 149 amino acids accounted for the activation ability. Fusion proteins of GST and CREB-H lacking the putative transmembrane domain were produced in bacteria and purified by glutathione�Sepharose 4B. The Gel mobility shift assays revealed that CREB-H did not bind to the C/EBP, AP-1 and NF-B elements but specifically bound to CRE and the box-B element. Luciferase reporter assays demonstrated that like BBF-2, CREB-H activated transcription via the box-B element and that a deletion of the putative transmembrane domain increased the activation of reporter expression significantly. Using COS7 cells, a fusion protein of GFP and full-length CREB-H was localized in reticular structures surrounding the nucleus, whereas a fusion protein of GFP and a deletion mutant lacking the putative transmembrane domain was mainly in the nucleus.

	     	  	      	     	11358960		      Co-activation; TF PPI	       Human	     Strong When incubated together, RBP2 was retained with GST-ER/RAR/GR/VDR (nuclear receptors) beads but not GST or GST-YKT6 (vesicle transport) beads.  Immunoblotting shows that RBP2 and ER are coimmunoprecipitated from lysates of cotransfected cells, showing they interact together.  Binding assay using ER bound to ER element conjugated to agarose beads shows that RBP2 are retained together only when ER is present, suggesting RBP2 could form a complex with ER bound to DNA. Cotransfection study with ER, Rbp2, and ERE-luciferase reporter (and also with RAR, VDR, and GR) shows significant ER-mediated induction of ERE-luc. Depletion of Rbp2 using its antisense construct significantly inhibited activation by ER and RAR. In RB- cell line, ER-medicated transcription was dramatically enhanced only when both RB and RBP2 were present.

  			   		   		Tim Hughes			       TF Gene	       DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	Cart1 is a homeodomain protein that binds preferentially to the palindromic repeats of the sequence 5'-TAAT-3' with a three base pair insertion (P3 element) (PMID: 9847249), as determined by gel-shift assay.  Reporter cotransfection assays have yielded different results regarding whether Cart1 is a transcriptional activator or repressor, with (PMID: 12390248) describing it as an activator and (PMID: 8756334) describing it as a repressor.  In the latter study, this repression was mediated by footprint II, an AT-rich element that functions as an inhibitory site of prolactin gene expression in nonpituitary cells and which was used to clone Cart-1.	8756334	Transactivation	Human	Not Selected	Reporter cotransfection assays describe it as a repressor.  In the latter study, this repression was mediated by footprint II, an AT-rich element that functions as an inhibitory site of prolactin gene expression in nonpituitary cells and which was used to clone Cart-1.

      217082		hepatic leukemia factor		 Zipper-Type Group/Leucine Zipper Family     Shannan HoSui	       TF Gene	       DNA-Binding: sequence-specific  HLF is a transcription factor whose binding specificity to the GTTACGTAAT consensus site was determined by an in vitro selection/amplification assay.  Binding was confirmed by competitive EMSA.  HLF acts as a transcriptional activator in several cell types, as determined by CAT reporter gene assays.    8065331		DNA Binding Human Strong      An HLF consensus DNA-binding site (GTTACGTAAT) was determined by a modified selective amplification and binding assay (SAAB) procedure. EMSA was performed to confirm that the consensus sequence represented a high-affinity HLF-binding site with an oligonucleotide containing the consensus site with and without 100-fold excess unlabelled competitor DNAs. The HLF complex was fully inhibited by an excess of unlabelled HLF consensus site and unaffected by a 100-fold excess of an unrelated binding site for the PBX1 protein. SAAB was also performed for E2A-HLF fusion protein, which bound to the same sequence but with tighter adherance to the the consensus than wt HLF.The transcriptional regulatory properties of wt HLF and E2A-HLF were investigated by cotransfection of expression vectors into mammalian cells along with reporter constructs containing a CAT gene under control of either the HSV TK or liver, bone, and kidney alkaline phosphatase promoters linked to concatamerized binding sites. In CV-1 cells, HLF strongly activated reporter gene transcription through HLF consensus binding sites and was a less potent activator of reporters containing VTG II sties.

an orphan nuclear receptor able to bind the motif WAWNTRGGTCA called RORE (ROR [retinoid acid related orphan receptor] response element).	  12021280 DNA Binding		Human	  Strong     Coste and Rodriguez (2002) determined that REV-ERB-alpha transfected and expressed in human hepatic cells specifically repressed APOC3 promoter activity. By deletion and site-directed mutagenesis experiments, they showed that REV-ERB-alpha bound to an element in the proximal promoter of the APOC3 gene that is also a ROR-alpha-1 element.       					 	      	       12150932		   DNA Binding	     Human		   Strong   Mammalian circadian rhythms are generated by a feedback loop in which BMAL1 and CLOCK, players of the positive limb, activate transcription of the cryptochrome and period genes, components of the negative limb. Bmal1 and Per transcription cycles display nearly opposite phases and are thus governed by different mechanisms. Here, authors identify the orphan nuclear receptor REV-ERBalpha as the major regulator of cyclic Bmal1 transcription. Circadian Rev-erbalpha expression is controlled by components of the general feedback loop. Thus, REV-ERBalpha constitutes a molecular link through which components of the negative limb drive antiphasic expression of components of the positive limb. While REV-ERBalpha influences the period length and affects the phase-shifting properties of the clock, it is not required for circadian rhythm

    		       	   		 		  	       	     	15735663     TF PPI  Human	Strong Athors show that overexpression of hsTAF12 potentiates ATF7-induced transcriptional activation through direct interaction with In support of this conclusion, chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments confirm the interaction of ATF7 with TAF12 on an ATF7-responsive promoter, in the absence of any artificial overexpression of both proteins.

																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																					     	     Sarav Sundararajan	      TF Gene	DNA-Binding: sequence-specific	      		   11278933	   DNA Binding	      Mouse  Strong	 EMSA assays show that ATF-7 can bind to CRE elements.   227644	      small nuclear RNA activating complex, polypeptide 4	  Helix-Turn-Helix Group/Myb Domain Family    Stuart Lithwick	  TF Gene				      DNA-Binding: non-sequence-specific; Basal Transcription Factor; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding       Snapc4 (referred to as SNAP190 in the PMID) regulates the transcription of snRNA genes by RNA Polymerase II and III as a part of the SNAPc multiprotein complex. In-vitro translated Snapc4 co-immunoprecipitates with in-vitro translated SNAPc subunit SNAP45. However, Snapc4 does not co-immunoprecipitate with SNAPc subunits SNAP50 and SNAP43 (data discussed but not shown in the PMID). Snapc4 binds to the proximal sequence element (PSE) of the U6 SnRNA promoter transcribed by RNA Polymerase II as demonstrated by EMSA assay and verified by supershift assay. Removal of Snapc4 from HeLa whole cell extracts by immunodepletion leads to significant decreases in transcription from U1 and U6 snRNA promoters as demonstrated in an in-vitro transcription assay.	9418884	Co-activation; DNA Binding; TF PPI	Human	Strong	Snapc4 (referred to as SNAP190 in this PMID) co-immunoprecipitated with SNAP45, another SNAPc complex subunit, in a co-immunoprecipitation assay in which   SNAP45 in-vitro translated in reticulocyte lysate was immunoprecipitated using anti-SNAP45, and Snapc4 was detected through Western blotting using anti-Snapc4. SNAP45 also co-immunoprecipitated with Snapc4 in a reciprocal experiment.A mobility shift, representative of Snapc4 (referred to as SNAP190 in this PMID) interacting with the proximal sequence element (PSE) of the RNA Polymerase II U6 SnRNA promoter was observed in an in-vitro EMSA assay in which in-vitro translated SNAPc complex was incubated with a labeled probe corresponding to the PSE. The presence of Snapc4 within the complex bound to the PSE was verified through a Supershift assay using anti-Snapc4.A sharp decrease in transcription from the U1 and U6 snRNA promoters was observed in an in-vitro transcription assay as a result of the progressive depletion of Snapc4 from HeLa whole cell extracts using anti-Snapc4, and was reversed through the addition of SNAPc to immunodepleted cell extract.

polymerase (RNA) II (DNA directed) polypeptide B    Enzyme Group/DNA Polymerase-Beta Family		 Shannan HoSui	TF Gene	  DNA-Binding: non-sequence-specific; Basal Transcription Factor; Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding	RPB2 is the second largest subunit of RNA polymerase II. Together with RPB1, it forms a cleft into which duplex DNA and DNA-RNA can fit.	10784442	DNA Binding; Non-specific DNA; TF PPI	Other	Strong	X-ray diffraction from 3D crystals of RNA pol II was used to determine the general architecture and DNA-binding of RNA pol II.  The two largest subunits, Rpb1 and Rpb2, form distinct masses with a deep cleft between them. Each of the small subunits occurs in a single copy, arrayed around the periphery. The structure is cross-strutted by elements of Rpb1 and Rpb2 that traverse the cleft: A helix of Rpb1 bridges the cleft, and the COOH-terminal region of Rpb2 extends to the opposite side. The Rpb1-Rpb2 complex is anchored at one end by a subassembly of Rpb3, Rpb10, Rpb11, and Rpb12. The floor of the Rpb1-Rpb2 cleft supports duplex DNA and the DNA-RNA hybrid.

MKL/myocardin-like 2		     		Jared Roach   TF Gene	    Transcription Factor Binding: tf co-factor binding Srong evidence for working as a co-factor with SRF.  12944485	   Co-activation      Human   Strong	    co-factor Abstract: Megakaryoblastic leukemia 1 (MKL1) is a myocardin-related transcription factor that we found strongly activated serum response element (SRE)-dependent reporter genes through its direct binding to serum response factor (SRF). The c-fos SRE is regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase phosphorylation of ternary complex factor (TCF) but is also regulated by a RhoA-dependent pathway. The mechanism of this pathway is unclear. Since MKL1 (also known as MAL, BSAC, and MRTF-A) is broadly expressed, we assessed its role in serum induction of c-fos and other SRE-regulated genes with a dominant negative MKL1 mutant (DN-MKL1) and RNA interference (RNAi). We found that DN-MKL1 and RNAi specifically blocked SRE-dependent reporter gene activation by serum and RhoA. Complete inhibition by RNAi required the additional inhibition of the related factor MKL2 (MRTF-B), showing the redundancy of these factors. DN-MKL1 reduced the late stage of serum induction of endogenous c-fos expression, suggesting that the TCF- and RhoA-dependent pathways contribute to temporally distinct phases of c-fos expression. Furthermore, serum induction of two TCF-independent SRE target genes, SRF and vinculin, was nearly completely blocked by DN-MKL1. Finally, the RBM15-MKL1 fusion protein formed by the t(1;22) translocation of acute megakaryoblastic leukemia had a markedly increased ability to activate SRE reporter genes, suggesting that its activation of SRF target genes may contribute to leukemogenesis. Method for EMSA:Gel mobility shift assays. MKL1 was in vitro transcribed and translated from pcDNA3.1-MKL1-HA, which contains a T7 promoter upstream of MKL1 and a C-terminal HA tag, with an STP3 kit (Novagen). In vitro-translated MKL1 (5 to 8 �l) and bacterially expressed SRF (amino acids 114 to 508) (10 ng) were used with a high-affinity SRF binding site, XGL, as a probe (47). SRF (amino acids 114 to 508) with an N-terminal polyhistidine tag was expressed in pET28b in E. coli and purified with a nickel-chelate resin (Novagen). The double-stranded oligonucleotide probe XGL was end labeled with [-32P]ATP and T4 polynucleotide kinase. The samples were incubated with 1 ng of probe in 20 �l of binding buffer (40 mM KCl, 10 mM Tris [pH 7.5], 1 mM EDTA, 0.5 mM dithiothreitol, 5% glycerol, 60 mM spermidine, 1 �g of sheared herring sperm DNA) for 1 h at room temperature and then separated on a 4% polyacrylamide gel in 0.25x TBE (25 mM Tris base, 25 mM boric acid, 1 mM EDTA), dried, and exposed to film.

non-sequence-specific; Transcription Regulatory Activity: heterochromatin interaction/binding	The mammalian SWI/SNF-related complexes facilitate gene transcription by remodeling chromatin using the energy of ATP hydrolysis, and may interact with site-specific transcription factors or other cofactors. Mass spectrometric analysis and immunoblotting demonstrate the presence of ARID1B in SWI/SNF-related complexes. Co-precipitation studies indicate that ARID1B associates with BRG1 and hBRM, essential ATPase subunits of SWI/SNF-related complexes. Analysis of DNA-binding behaviour in a in a DNA pull-down assay indicates that ARID1B binds DNA in a non-sequence-specific manner. It interacts with Smad1 by GST pulldown assays and a Gal4 protein-protein interaction assay in HEK293 cells. mZnfB localizes exclusively in the nucleus by HA-tagging and represses transcription of a Gal4- , TGF-&#946;-  and BMP- reporters.	12370310	TF PPI; Transactivation	Human; Mouse; Other	Strong	mZnf8 interacts with Smad1 by in vitro GST pulldown assays HEK293 cells cotransfected with GAL4DB-Smad1, various amounts of Znf8-vp16 and the Gal4 reporter construct demonstrate that Znf8-vp16 dramatically increased the reporter activity in cells transfected with GAL4DB-Smad1 suggesting that mZnf8 and Smad1 interact in living mammalian cells. HA-mZnf8 tagged/expressed in COS-M6 cells (with localization of the fusion protein detected with an anti-HA antibody) demonstrates that mZnfB localizes exclusively in the nucleus.mZnf8 fused with a GAL4DB represses transcription of the reporter compared to the GAL4DB alone. Overexpression of mZnf8 in HEK293 cells transfected with TGF-&#946; and BMP responsive enhancer (necessary for the transcriptional induction of mouse Smad6 by BMP stimulation) reporters demonstrates that mZnf8 represses both the TGF-&#946; and BMP reporters in a dose-dependent fashion which suggests that mZnf8 functions as a transcriptional repressor and interacts with Smad1 and Smad2 in mammalian cells.

      		      	 			   	  		 14527415	TF PPI; Transactivation	Human	Weak	The pol III complex contains traces of CK2, and CK2 associates with the U6 promoter region in vivo. Transcription requires CK2 phosphorylation of the pol III complex. In contrast, CK2 phosphorylation of TBP, Brf2, and Bdp1 combined is inhibitory. The results define a minimum core machinery, the ultimate target of regulatory mechanisms, capable of directing all steps of the transcription process-initiation, elongation, and termination-by a metazoan RNA polymerase, and suggest positive and negative regulatory roles for CK2 in transcription by pol III.

   		    	      	    			 		      15610520		  TF PPI Human		       Strong  Yeast 2 hybrid screen using the ligand-binding domain of human PPAR-alpha shows that COPR1 interacts with PPAR-alpha.  COPR2 is an alternative splice variant of COPR1 and homologue of rat NRBF-2.  Fusion products of COPR1 and COPR2 and their truncated versions with GAL4-DNA binding domain shows the presence of auto-activation domain. COPR1:PPAR interactions yield much higher reporter expression than COPR2:PPAR. Mutation of NR box on COPR1/COPR2 leads to decrease in reporter activity. Mutation of the AF-2 region of RXRalpha leads to decrease in reporter activity in yeast, which is also supported by mammlian two-hybrid studies.  COPR1/COPR2 partially represses RXR activity in HaCaT cells.
